summary: On projects located more than 120 radius kilometers from a designated city hall or hiring hall, the employer must either pay a subsistence allowance or provide camp accommodation.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 120 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall > 120 -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE) OR PROVIDE(CAMP)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary condition for an employee's eligibility for subsistence or camp accommodation, a key aspect of subsistence allowances.

name: Standard Daily Subsistence Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The standard subsistence rate is $150.00 per day worked or reported for, unless a specific location rate applies.
logical_representation: IF work_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> ALLOWANCE(150.00)
reasoning: The rule specifies the default monetary amount for the daily subsistence allowance.

name: Location-Specific Subsistence Rates
rule_text:
In the following areas, subsistence will be paid at a rate per day worked or reported for as noted:

| Athabasca | $170.00 |
| Bonnyville | $180 |
| Calgary | $180 |
| Camrose | $185 |
| Caroline | $125 |
| Canmore/Exshaw | $195 |
| Cold Lake | $165 |
| Drumheller | $180 |
| Edmonton | $180 |
| Edson | $175 |
| Forestburg | $130 |

summary: Subsistence rates vary by location, with specific amounts paid per day worked or reported for in designated areas. For example, Fort McMurray is $200, Grande Prairie is $205, and Caroline is $125.
logical_representation: IF work_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> CASE project_location: 'Fort McMurray' -> ALLOWANCE(200.00), 'Grande Prairie' -> ALLOWANCE(205.00), 'Athabasca' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Bonnyville' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Calgary' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Camrose' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Caroline' -> ALLOWANCE(125.00), 'Canmore/Exshaw' -> ALLOWANCE(195.00), 'Cold Lake' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Drumheller' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Edmonton' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Edson' -> ALLOWANCE(175.00), 'Forestburg' -> ALLOWANCE(130.00), 'Fox Creek' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Grande Cache' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Hanna' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Hardisty/Wainwright' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'High Level' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Hinton' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Lethbridge' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Lloydminster' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Medicine Hat' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Peace River' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Pincher Creek/Waterton' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Red Deer' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Rocky Mountain House' -> ALLOWANCE(190.00), 'Stettler' -> ALLOWANCE(190.00), 'Swan Hills' -> ALLOWANCE(150.00), 'Valley View' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Vermillion' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Wabasca' -> ALLOWANCE(200.00), 'Whitecourt' -> ALLOWANCE(155.00) ELSE ALLOWANCE(150.00)
reasoning: This rule provides a list of exceptions to the standard subsistence rate based on geographic location, which is a core function of subsistence allowance policies.

name: Review of Subsistence Amounts
rule_text: These amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The subsistence allowance rates will be reviewed by a joint committee if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_change == true -> TRIGGER_REVIEW(subsistence_amounts)
reasoning: This rule governs the process for updating subsistence allowances, an administrative component of the policy.

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Sites (>475km)
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 or more radius kilometers away, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just for days worked.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km >= 475 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall >= 475 -> APPLY_ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE, 7_DAYS_PER_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule modifies the payment schedule for subsistence based on extreme distance, directly impacting how the allowance is calculated and paid.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture and Waiver
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: An employee will lose their subsistence allowance if they are absent, but this can be waived if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF employee_absent == true AND is_absence_preauthorized == false -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (absenteeism) under which an employee loses their entitlement to the subsistence allowance, making it a key rule for allowance administration.

name: Additional Subsistence Day for Travel
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations. This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (e.g., receipt or registration verification).
summary: Non-local employees on subsistence projects over 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence for either the day before starting or the day after finishing work, provided they show proof of accommodation.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == false AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 200 AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_ACCOMMODATION' -> PAY(1_DAY_SUBSISTENCE_ON_TRAVEL_DAY)
reasoning: This rule provides an additional monetary benefit related to travel for subsistence projects, directly falling under the scope of subsistence allowances.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance Rates (Effective June 1, 2025)
rule_text:
Effective June 1, 2025 (second Sunday following ratification), there is a scheduled increase to initial and terminal travel which will be paid as follows from the above:

| One Hundred and Twenty (120) - Two Hundred (200) Radius Kilometers | $116.00 each way |
| Two Hundred (200) - Three Hundred (300) Radius Kilometers | $166.00 each way |
| Three Hundred (300) - Three Hundred and Seventy-Five (375) Radius Kilometers | $200.00 each way |
| Three Hundred and Seventy-Five (375) - Four Hundred and Seventy-Five (475) Radius Kilometers | $297.00 each way |
summary: Starting June 1, 2025, initial and terminal travel allowances will be paid each way based on project distance: $116 (120-200km), $166 (200-300km), $200 (300-375km), and $297 (375-475km).
logical_representation: IF validity_start_date >= '2025-06-01' -> CASE project_distance_from_city_hall_km: (120, 200] -> PAY(116.00_EACH_WAY), (200, 300] -> PAY(166.00_EACH_WAY), (300, 375] -> PAY(200.00_EACH_WAY), (375, 475] -> PAY(297.00_EACH_WAY)
reasoning: This rule defines specific monetary amounts for travel allowances based on distance, a core element of subsistence and travel policies.

name: Airfare as Travel Allowance Alternative
rule_text: or actual airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: Instead of the standard distance-based travel allowance, an employee can be reimbursed for the actual cost of their airfare if they provide proof of air travel.
logical_representation: IF travel_mode == 'AIR' AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_AIRFARE' -> PAY(ACTUAL_AIRFARE)
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative calculation method for the travel allowance, which is a key part of subsistence and travel policies.

name: Fort McMurray Initial and Terminal Travel Rate
rule_text: Initial and Terminal travel for any project which falls within one- hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall will be two hundred and ninety-seven dollars ($297.00).
summary: For any project within a 100km radius of Fort McMurray city hall, the initial and terminal travel allowance is a flat rate of $297.00.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' AND job_location_radius_km <= 100 -> PAY(297.00_FOR_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific travel allowance for a particular geographic area, making it a location-based subsistence rule.

name: No Travel Allowance with Client-Provided Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no travel allowance will be paid to the employee.
logical_representation: IF client_provided_transport == true -> FORFEIT(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition under which the travel allowance entitlement is nullified, directly impacting subsistence payments.

name: Initial/Terminal Travel for Very Remote Projects (>475km)
rule_text: On jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial and terminal travel amounts will be mutually agreed between the Local Lodge and the Employer to a maximum of four hundred and fifty-five dollars ($455.00) each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: For jobs more than 475km away, initial and terminal travel pay is mutually agreed upon, up to a maximum of $455.00 each way, or the actual cost of airfare with proof.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 475 -> PAY(MUTUALLY_AGREED_AMOUNT) WITH MAX(455.00_EACH_WAY) OR (IF travel_mode == 'AIR' AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_AIRFARE' -> PAY(ACTUAL_AIRFARE))
reasoning: This rule defines the travel allowance calculation for projects at extreme distances, a key part of a comprehensive subsistence policy.

name: Review of Initial and Terminal Travel Amounts
rule_text: Initial and terminal travel amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The initial and terminal travel allowance rates will be reviewed by a joint committee if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_change == true -> TRIGGER_REVIEW(initial_terminal_travel_amounts)
reasoning: This rule governs the process for updating initial and terminal travel allowances, which is an administrative aspect of subsistence policies.

name: Initial Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay- off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid out after an employee has been on the job for 15 calendar days, or at layoff if it occurs sooner.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job >= 15 OR employee_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(INITIAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule dictates the timing and conditions for paying the travel allowance, which is an administrative aspect of subsistence benefits.

name: Terminal Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The terminal travel allowance is paid when the employee is laid off.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(TERMINAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule specifies the event that triggers the payment of the terminal travel allowance, an administrative component of subsistence policies.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Pay on Quit or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before their travel allowance is paid, they forfeit any right to that payment.
logical_representation: IF employee_status IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED_FOR_CAUSE'] -> FORFEIT(OUTSTANDING_TRAVEL_PAYMENTS)
reasoning: This rule outlines conditions for forfeiture of the travel allowance based on employment status, directly affecting the payment of subsistence benefits.

name: Documentation for Subsistence Qualification
rule_text: To qualify for the subsistence allowance under Article 16.01, the member, will supply two (2) of the following documents as verification of their name and current address. It is understood that the Employer will ensure any copies of such documents will be handled in accordance with PIPA regulations. - Any government issued identification - Utility Bill - Bank Statement - Vehicle Registration - Housing Rental Agreement - Mortgage Documentation - Land Title - Credit Card Statement - Income Tax Assessment - Property Tax Assessment - Employment Insurance
summary: To qualify for subsistence, an employee must provide two forms of identification from an approved list (such as government ID, utility bill, or bank statement) to verify their name and current address.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == 'SUBSISTENCE_QUALIFICATION' -> REQUIRE(2_DOCUMENTS_FOR_ID_AND_ADDRESS_VERIFICATION)
reasoning: This rule sets a procedural requirement for an employee to become eligible for subsistence, making it a foundational rule for the allowance.

name: Ineligibility of Local Residents for Subsistence Benefits
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel
summary: On a project designated for subsistence, employees who already live in the project area are not eligible for the accommodation allowance or initial/terminal travel pay.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true -> INELIGIBLE_FOR(ACCOMMODATION_ALLOWANCE, INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule defines an exclusion criterion for subsistence benefits based on an employee's residency, which is a fundamental aspect of subsistence policies.

name: Daily Travel for Local Residents on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 16.01 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: Local residents on a subsistence project who live more than 45km from the project site are not eligible for accommodation allowance but are entitled to receive daily travel payments.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true AND distance_from_residence_to_project_km > 45 -> ELIGIBLE_FOR(DAILY_TRAVEL_PAYMENT)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific travel benefit for a subset of employees (local residents) under certain conditions, making it a subsistence-related rule.

name: Daily Travel for Non-Local Residents on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the free zone to the temporary domicile and return.
summary: On a subsistence project, non-local employees whose temporary lodging is more than 45km from the job site will either be given transportation to the job or paid $0.69 per km for travel from their temporary lodging to the job and back.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == false AND distance_from_temp_domicile_to_project_km > 45 AND work_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION) OR PAY(0.69 * travel_distance_from_free_zone_km * 2)
reasoning: This rule describes a daily travel benefit specifically for non-local employees on a subsistence project, which is a core component of subsistence and remote work allowances.

name: Fort McMurray Transport for Subsistence Employees
rule_text: In Ft. McMurray, subsistence employees will be provided transportation to and from the job site as per current arrangements under the Agreement.
summary: In Fort McMurray, employees receiving subsistence will be provided with transportation to and from the job site according to the agreement's current arrangements.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule outlines a location-specific transportation benefit for subsistence employees, making it a key rule within the subsistence allowance topic.

name: Weekly Payday Schedule
rule_text: Employees shall be paid weekly during working hours, not later than Thursday.
summary: Employees are to be paid on a weekly basis, during their regular working hours, and the payment must be issued no later than Thursday of that week.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(PAYMENT_FREQUENCY = 'WEEKLY') AND CONSTRAINT(PAYMENT_DAY <= THU) AND CONSTRAINT(PAYMENT_TIME = 'working_hours')
reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental frequency and timing for employee payment, which is a core aspect of compensation for labor time.

name: Pay Period Holdback Limit
rule_text: In no case shall more than five (5) regular working days be held back in any one payroll period.
summary: An employer is not permitted to hold back more than five regular working days' worth of pay from an employee in any single payroll period.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(pay_holdback_days (llm) <= 5)
reasoning: This rule sets a maximum limit on the delay between work performed and its payment, directly governing the administration of labor compensation.

name: Final Pay on Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or discharged from the service of the Employer shall receive their wages and all monies owing and their Employment Insurance Contribution Certificate.
summary: Upon being laid off or discharged, an employee must receive all outstanding wages and any other money owed, along with their Employment Insurance documentation.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> PROVIDE(FINAL_PAY) AND PROVIDE(EI_CERTIFICATE)
reasoning: This rule outlines the employer's obligation to provide final compensation and required documentation when employment is terminated, which is a final settlement for labor worked.

name: Termination Slip Requirement
rule_text: the employee shall receive an Employer termination slip which shall show either their net pay and deductions, or the basic factors from which their pay will be calculated including: total pay hours, travel allowance and transportation allowances, subsistence, etc.
summary: When laid off or discharged, an employee must be given a termination slip that details the calculation of their final pay, including hours, allowances, and deductions.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> PROVIDE(TERMINATION_SLIP_WITH_PAY_DETAILS)
reasoning: This rule pertains to the procedural and informational requirements of final pay, which is an administrative component of labor compensation.

name: Payment Method by Direct Deposit
rule_text: Pay shall be by direct deposit.
summary: All payments to employees must be made via direct deposit.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(PAYMENT_METHOD = 'DIRECT_DEPOSIT')
reasoning: This rule specifies the mandatory method for delivering compensation for labor.

name: Final Pay Timing for Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: and the Employer shall direct deposit monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday, and Recognized Holidays.
summary: For an employee who is laid off or discharged, the employer must issue final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment (ROE) by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> CONSTRAINT(FINAL_PAY_DUE_DATE <= 'next_regular_pay_period')
reasoning: This rule establishes the deadline for issuing final payment upon termination, a critical part of the labor compensation process.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty for Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Should the Employer fail to comply with this provision (excluding the reference to the Record of Employment), the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates for each day they are kept waiting exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of pay.
summary: If an employer is late providing final pay to a laid off or discharged employee, they must pay a penalty of 8 hours of straight-time pay for each business day the payment is delayed, up to a maximum of 40 hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] AND is_final_pay_late (llm) == true -> PAY(PENALTY, 8_HOURS_ST * final_pay_delay_days (llm), MAX=40_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule specifies a financial penalty for failing to meet the final payment deadline, directly impacting the total compensation for worked time.

name: Final Pay Timing for Quit
rule_text: When an employee quits of their own volition, the Employer shall direct deposit all monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Recognized Holidays.
summary: When an employee resigns, the employer must issue their final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment (ROE) by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' -> CONSTRAINT(FINAL_PAY_DUE_DATE <= 'next_regular_pay_period')
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final compensation when an employee quits, which is a key part of the labor payment process.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty for Quit
rule_text: If the Employer fails to comply with this requirement within five (5) working days after the specified pay day, the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates.
summary: If an employer is more than five working days late in issuing final pay to an employee who has quit, the employee is entitled to a penalty payment of 8 hours at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND final_pay_delay_days (llm) > 5 -> PAY(PENALTY, 8_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for late final payment to a resigned employee, impacting the total compensation for their worked time.

name: Pay Shortage Correction Timeline
rule_text: If on an employee's weekly paycheck, they are shorted pay, the employee is required to notify the Employer immediately in writing. The Employer shall provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and Recognized Holidays after receiving the notification of the shortage in writing.
summary: If an employee's pay is short, they must notify the employer in writing. The employer then has 10 business days from the date of receiving the notification to correct the shortage on a future paycheck.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_notification_received (llm) == true -> CONSTRAINT(PAY_ADJUSTMENT_DUE_DAYS = 10)
reasoning: This rule establishes the procedure and deadline for correcting payment errors, ensuring accurate compensation for labor.

name: Penalty for Late Pay Shortage Correction
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Employer will pay one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day the employee is kept waiting from the date the notification of shortage was received in writing by the Employer to a maximum of seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
summary: If an employer fails to correct a pay shortage within the 10-day window, they must pay a penalty of $100 per day of delay, starting from the notification date, up to a $700 maximum.
logical_representation: IF pay_adjustment_delay_days (llm) > 10 -> PAY(PENALTY, $100 * (pay_adjustment_delay_days (llm)), MAX=$700)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to correct pay errors in a timely manner, which directly relates to ensuring proper compensation for worked time.

name: Bereavement Pay Eligibility - Service Requirement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits...
summary: An employee becomes eligible for bereavement pay benefits after completing more than three years of continuous service with the same employer.
logical_representation: IF continuous_service_years (llm) > 3 AND validity_end_date < '2026-01-01' -> ENTITLEMENT(BEREAVEMENT_PAY)
reasoning: This rule defines a key eligibility condition (length of service) for receiving paid leave, which is a form of compensation for time not worked.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a results of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -in-Law, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Eligible employees can receive bereavement pay for up to three days of lost work to attend a funeral or memorial service for a specified family member. The pay is 8 hours per day at the employee's straight-time base rate.
logical_representation: IF deceased_relation (llm) IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] AND bereavement_leave_reason (llm) == 'ATTEND_FUNERAL_OR_MEMORIAL' -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * bereavement_days_taken (llm), MAX_DAYS=3)
reasoning: This rule specifies the amount, duration, and qualifying reasons for paid bereavement leave, which is a direct component of labor compensation rules.

name: Bereavement Eligibility Service Requirement Change (2026)
rule_text: January 1, 2026, continuous employment transitions to thirty (30) months.
summary: Effective January 1, 2026, the service requirement for bereavement pay eligibility changes from three years to thirty months of continuous employment.
logical_representation: IF validity_start_date >= '2026-01-01' AND validity_end_date < '2027-01-01' AND continuous_service_months (llm) > 30 -> ENTITLEMENT(BEREAVEMENT_PAY)
reasoning: This rule modifies a pre-existing eligibility condition for a paid leave benefit, falling under the administration of labor compensation.

name: Bereavement Eligibility Service Requirement Change (2027)
rule_text: January 1, 2027, continuous employment transitions to twenty-four (24) months.
summary: Effective January 1, 2027, the service requirement for bereavement pay eligibility is further reduced to twenty-four months of continuous employment.
logical_representation: IF validity_start_date >= '2027-01-01' AND continuous_service_months (llm) > 24 -> ENTITLEMENT(BEREAVEMENT_PAY)
reasoning: This rule further modifies a pre-existing eligibility condition for a paid leave benefit, falling under the administration of labor compensation.

name: Reporting Pay, Inclement Weather (Work Not Started)
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee reports to a job site but cannot start work due to bad weather, they are guaranteed two hours of pay. They are required to stay on site for this two-hour period unless a supervisor permits them to leave.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status (Unsupported) == 'NOT_STARTED' AND weather_condition (llm) == 'INCLEMENT' -> PAY(2_HOURS_ST) AND REQUIRE(REMAIN_ON_SITE(2_HOURS))
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment for showing up to work when work cannot begin due to weather. This is a form of guaranteed time/pay, which falls under the category of how labor time is compensated.

name: Minimum Pay, Inclement Weather (Work Started)
rule_text: When an employee has commenced work and is instructed to stop due to inclement weather, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall an employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: If work starts but is later stopped because of bad weather, the employee will be paid for the actual time they worked, with a guaranteed minimum payment of two hours.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status (Unsupported) == 'STARTED' AND weather_condition (llm) == 'INCLEMENT' -> PAY(MAX(daily_hours, 2_HOURS_ST))
reasoning: This rule sets a minimum payment floor for a workday that has been started but is cut short due to weather. This directly relates to the compensation for hours worked and guaranteed minimums, classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Reporting Pay, Work Not Available
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and is not given the opportunity to work because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day's work, they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: If an employee shows up for their shift and there is no work available, and they were not notified of this the previous day, they will receive two hours of pay and can leave the job site immediately.
logical_representation: IF work_availability (llm) == 'NOT_AVAILABLE' AND prior_day_notification (llm) == false -> PAY(2_HOURS_ST) AND ALLOW(LEAVE_SITE_IMMEDIATELY)
reasoning: This rule defines the compensation (reporting time) an employee is entitled to when they report for duty but no work is available. This is a minimum pay guarantee, which is a core component of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Minimum Pay, Work Stopped by Employer
rule_text: When an employee has started to work on their regular shift and is instructed to stop, they shall be paid for the actual time worked. In no case shall the employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: If an employee begins their regular shift and is later told to stop working by the employer, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay. If they worked longer than two hours, they are paid for their actual time worked.
logical_representation: IF work_stopped_by_employer (llm) == true -> PAY(MAX(daily_hours, 2_HOURS_ST))
reasoning: This rule establishes a general minimum payment for a partially worked day when the work is stopped by the employer. As it dictates a minimum compensation for time, it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Forfeiture of Minimum Pay, Employee Stops Work
rule_text: If an employee stops work for reasons of their own, and without the approval of the Employer, they shall be entitled to pay only for the hours actually worked in the day and minimum conditions shall not apply.
summary: If an employee chooses to stop working on their own accord without getting permission from the employer, they forfeit any right to minimum pay guarantees (like reporting time) and will only be paid for the exact hours they worked.
logical_representation: IF employee_initiated_stop (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(MINIMUM_PAY) AND PAY(daily_hours)
reasoning: This rule acts as an exception to the minimum pay guarantees. It defines a scenario where entitlements are voided, which is a critical aspect of calculating worked time and pay. Therefore, it is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Subsistence Receipt Date Requirement
rule_text: 1. Date
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the date of the transaction.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_date (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies a mandatory piece of information (date) required on a receipt for subsistence reimbursement, which is a condition for receiving the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt Establishment and Contact Person
rule_text: 2. Name of Establishment and Name of Contact Person if appropriate (see examples below) ABC Motel -Company letterhead receipt -Name of Contact Person not required B & B or Relative (non-registered) -Name of Contact Person required
summary: For subsistence reimbursement, the receipt must include the name of the establishment. It must also include a contact person's name if the accommodation is from a non-registered provider (e.g., B&B, relative), but this is not required for registered establishments (e.g., motel).
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_establishment_name (llm) == true) AND IF establishment_is_registered (llm) == false -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_contact_person (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies two distinct but related pieces of information required on a subsistence receipt: the establishment name (always required) and a contact person (conditionally required), both of which are prerequisites for the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt Address and Phone Number Requirement
rule_text: 3. Complete Address and Phone Number of the Establishment
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must include the complete address and phone number of the establishment.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_address_and_phone (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule mandates that a receipt for subsistence must contain the establishment's contact details, which is a condition for reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Employee Name Requirement
rule_text: 4. Employee's Full Name
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the employee's full name.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_employee_name (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule requires the employee's name on the receipt for a subsistence claim, a necessary condition for validating and processing the reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Reason for Cost Requirement
rule_text: 5. Reason/Description of Cost (including dates)
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must describe the reason for the cost and include the relevant dates.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_cost_reason (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule mandates a description of the cost on the subsistence receipt, which is a condition for claim validation and reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Total Cost Requirement
rule_text: 6. Total Cost
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the total cost paid.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_total_cost (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies that the total cost must be on the subsistence receipt, a fundamental requirement for processing the reimbursement.

name: Invalidity of Incomplete Subsistence Receipts
rule_text: A receipt without complete or required information will not be considered.
summary: A receipt for subsistence reimbursement that is missing any of the required information will be rejected and not considered for payment.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' AND receipt_is_complete (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE('SUBSISTENCE'))
reasoning: This rule defines the consequence of failing to meet the documentation requirements for subsistence, directly impacting the allowance entitlement. It serves as the enforcement clause for all preceding receipt requirements.

name: CWW, Normal Work Day
rule_text: The parties to this Agreement agree that the maximum of nine (9) hours shall constitute a normal days work beginning at 7:30 a.m. and ending at 5:00 p.m. (excluding a one-half hour (1/2) lunch break) may be utilized if restricted to Long Term Base Crew employees.
summary: For Long Term Base Crew employees on a Compressed Work Week, a normal workday is 9 hours, from 7:30 AM to 5:00 PM, with a 30-minute unpaid lunch break.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> SET(daily_hours_straight_time = 9)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard daily hours for a specific employee type and schedule, which is fundamental to calculating pay.

name: CWW, Normal Work Week
rule_text: ...the maximum normal work week shall be forty-five (45) hours beginning Monday at 7:30 a.m. and ending Friday at 5:00 p.m.
summary: The normal work week for employees on the Compressed Work Week schedule is 45 hours, Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> SET(weekly_hours_straight_time = 45)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard weekly hours for the Compressed Work Week schedule, forming the basis for overtime calculations.

name: EDO Entitlement, Annual
rule_text: With the understanding that this work schedule is utilized to compensate the employees for hours lost during the twenty-six (26) yearly earned days off (EDO's)...
summary: Employees on the Compressed Work Week are entitled to 26 Earned Days Off (EDOs) per year, which is compensated for by the 45-hour work week.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> PROVIDE(earned_days_off_entitlement (llm) = 26_per_year)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to a specific number of paid days off, which is a core component of time and compensation.

name: EDO Scheduling, Scheduled vs Flex
rule_text: Of the twentysix (26) EDO's, eighteen (18) will be scheduled by Suncor and the remaining eight (8) will be designated as flex EDO's to be taken as mutually agreed between the employee and the supervisor.
summary: Of the 26 annual Earned Days Off, 18 are scheduled by Suncor and 8 are flexible EDOs scheduled by mutual agreement between the employee and supervisor.
logical_representation: SET(earned_day_off_type (llm) = 'SCHEDULED', count=18) AND SET(earned_day_off_type (llm) = 'FLEX', count=8)
reasoning: This rule outlines the process and responsibility for scheduling time off, which affects labor planning and pay.

name: Long Term Base Crew, Definition
rule_text: It is understood that when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew employee.
summary: An employee is considered "Long Term Base Crew" and automatically placed on the Compressed Work Week schedule if they are hired with the expectation of working for more than six weeks.
logical_representation: IF expected_employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW') AND APPLY_PAY_RULES('CWW')
reasoning: This rule defines a specific class of employee, which is a condition for several other pay and scheduling rules.

name: Early Termination Pay Adjustment, Long Term Crew
rule_text: Should an employee be terminated prior to working six (6) weeks, an adjustment shall be made in accordance with the terms of Clause b).
summary: If a Long Term Base Crew employee is terminated before working six weeks, their pay will be retroactively adjusted to match the terms for short-term employees (i.e., the 9th hour of each day is paid at 1.5x).
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' AND employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND employment_duration_weeks (llm) < 6 AND daily_hours > 8 -> RETROACTIVE_PAY(hours_between(8, 9), 1.5)
reasoning: This is a specific pay calculation rule triggered by the event of early termination, altering previous pay calculations.

name: Short Term Employee, 9th Hour Pay
rule_text: It is understood that when employees are hired with the intentions of short-term employment (defined as less than six (6) weeks from the date of hire) that they will be paid time and one-half (1 1/2) for the ninth (9th) hour.
summary: Employees hired for short-term work (less than six weeks) are paid time and a half for the 9th hour worked each day.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'SHORT_TERM' AND expected_employment_duration_weeks (llm) < 6 AND daily_hours > 8 -> PAY(hours_between(8, 9), 1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific overtime calculation for a class of employee based on daily hours worked.

name: Employee Transition, Short to Long Term
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms (except as outlined in item (e) below).
summary: If a short-term employee works for more than six weeks, they are reclassified as Long Term Crew and paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules, unless it's a Plant Shutdown.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'SHORT_TERM' AND employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 AND event (Unsupported) != 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW')
reasoning: This rule defines a change in employee status based on tenure, which directly impacts their pay and scheduling rules.

name: Overtime, Scheduled EDO
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the scheduled eighteen (18) days off will be at time and one half (1 ½) for the first twelve (12) hours and double-time (2) paid thereafter.
summary: When working on one of the 18 Suncor-scheduled Earned Days Off, employees are paid 1.5x for the first 12 hours and 2.0x for all hours after that.
logical_representation: IF work_on_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND earned_day_off_type (llm) == 'SCHEDULED' -> PAY(hours_up_to(12), 1.5) AND PAY(hours_after(12), 2.0)
reasoning: This rule specifies tiered overtime rates for working on a specific type of scheduled day off.

name: Overtime, Sundays and Statutory Holidays
rule_text: Double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: All hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines a premium pay rate for specific calendar days, which is a standard worked time rule.

name: Overtime, Flex EDO with Insufficient Notice
rule_text: If an employee is asked to work their scheduled flex day off without being given forty- eight (48) hours notice, then the employee will be paid overtime at time and one half (1 ½) for up to twelve (12) hours...
summary: If an employee works on a flex EDO without at least 48 hours' notice, they are paid 1.5x for the first 12 hours, unless it's a Sunday or Statutory Holiday.
logical_representation: IF work_on_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND earned_day_off_type (llm) == 'FLEX' AND work_notice_hours (llm) < 48 AND day_of_week != 'SUN' AND is_stat_holiday == false -> PAY(hours_up_to(12), 1.5)
reasoning: This rule outlines a specific overtime scenario based on insufficient notice for working on a day off.

name: Overtime, Flex EDO with Insufficient Notice on Sun/Stat
rule_text: ...except on Sundays and Statutory Holidays where double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked.
summary: If an employee is required to work a flex EDO with less than 48 hours' notice, and that day falls on a Sunday or Statutory Holiday, all hours worked are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF work_on_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND earned_day_off_type (llm) == 'FLEX' AND work_notice_hours (llm) < 48 AND (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule is an exception to the insufficient notice rule, applying a higher premium based on the day of the week or holiday status.

name: Termination Pay Adjustment, Unused Flex EDO
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: Upon termination, if a long-term employee has not taken a flex EDO in the preceding six weeks, any regular hours they worked beyond 240 during that period will be paid out at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' AND employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND flex_edo_taken_in_lookback (llm) == false AND lookback_period_weeks (llm) == 6 -> PAY(hours_in_excess_of(240, regular_hours_in_lookback (llm)), OT_RATE)
reasoning: This is a specific pay calculation rule triggered by termination and tied to the usage of banked earned time off.

name: Flex EDO, Employee Notice Requirement
rule_text: The employee will provide a minimum of seven (7) days notice when requesting flex. EDO's. Special circumstances will be considered by the supervisor wherein a shorter notice period may be allowed.
summary: Employees must give at least seven days' notice when requesting a flex EDO, though supervisors may approve requests with shorter notice in special cases.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: Employee request for flex EDO requires MIN(7_days_notice) unless supervisor approves exception.
reasoning: This is a procedural rule governing how employees can use their entitled time off, which affects scheduling and labor management.

name: Flex EDO Payout, Forfeiture
rule_text: ...and that overtime payment will not be made for flex days not taken by the employee with the exception of those circumstances outlined in items b) and c) above
summary: Employees will not be paid out for unused flex EDOs, except under specific circumstances such as early termination or termination without having taken a recent flex day.
logical_representation: IF NOT (employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND (termination_condition_b (llm) == true OR termination_condition_c (llm) == true)) -> FORFEIT(PAY_FOR_UNUSED_FLEX_EDO)
reasoning: This rule establishes a 'use it or lose it' policy for an entitlement, with specific exceptions, which is a core compensation rule.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedule, Short Term Hires
rule_text: During a period of Plant Shutdown, all employees hired with the intentions of short- term employment shall be paid based on five (5) eight (8) hour days Monday to Friday or four (4) ten (10) hour days Monday to Thursday and or Tuesday to Friday.
summary: During a Plant Shutdown, short-term employees will work a schedule of either five 8-hour days (Mon-Fri) or four 10-hour days (Mon-Thu or Tue-Fri).
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' AND employee_type (llm) == 'SHORT_TERM' -> APPLY_PAY_RULES(schedule_type = '5x8' OR schedule_type = '4x10_mon_thu' OR schedule_type = '4x10_tue_fri')
reasoning: This rule defines specific work schedules for a particular event and employee type, which is foundational to calculating work time.

name: Plant Shutdown Employment Term, Short Term Hires
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than six (6) weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a Plant Shutdown will remain classified as short-term employees for pay purposes for the entire duration of the shutdown, even if it exceeds six weeks.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' AND employee_is_hired_for_shutdown (llm) == true -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'SHORT_TERM') FOR DURATION(event)
reasoning: This rule creates an exception to the standard employee classification transition rule, based on a specific work event, which affects pay calculation.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedule, Long Term Crew
rule_text: All Long Term Base Crew employees shall remain on the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a Plant Shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees continue to be paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules, including overtime for work on scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' AND employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('CWW') AND APPLY_PAY_RULES('CLAUSE_C')
reasoning: This rule confirms that the standard pay and overtime rules for a specific employee class are maintained during a special event.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Approved Worksites
rule_text:
- □ Shell Scotford, Ft. Saskatchewan, Alberta
- □ Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, Redwater, Alberta
- □ Northwest Redwater, Alberta
summary: The 9/80 work schedule is only approved for use at Shell Scotford, Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, and Northwest Redwater sites.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) IN ['Shell Scotford, Ft. Saskatchewan, Alberta', 'Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, Redwater, Alberta', 'Northwest Redwater, Alberta'] -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('9/80')
reasoning: This rule defines the geographic locations where a specific work schedule (9/80) is applicable, which is a fundamental condition for how work time is categorized and paid.

name: 9/80 Schedule, General Definition
rule_text: This work week averages to forty (40) hours straight time over a two-week period and is generally known as the 9/80 schedule.
summary: The 9/80 schedule is a two-week cycle that averages 40 straight-time hours per week.
logical_representation: DEFINE(schedule_type='9/80') WHERE average_weekly_hours_over_2_weeks == 40
reasoning: This rule defines the core structure and average hours of the 9/80 schedule, which is essential for categorizing labor hours.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Major Shutdown Exclusion
rule_text: It is intended for on-going work and does not operate in 'major shutdown' situations.
summary: The 9/80 work schedule is not applicable during major shutdown situations.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' -> FORFEIT(schedule_type='9/80')
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition (major shutdown) under which the 9/80 schedule and its associated time-keeping rules do not apply.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Regular Hours (Mon-Thu)
rule_text: The regular work week will consist of four (4) nine (9) hour straight time days Monday to Thursday...
summary: In the first week of a 9/80 schedule, the regular workday from Monday to Thursday is 9 hours at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> MAX(9_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard straight-time hours for specific days within the 9/80 schedule, which is a core component of labor time categorization.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Regular Hours (Friday)
rule_text: ...and one (1) eight (8) hour straight time day on Friday in the first week.
summary: In the first week of a 9/80 schedule, the regular workday on Friday is 8 hours at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> MAX(8_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard straight-time hours for a specific day (Friday) within the 9/80 schedule, which is a core component of labor time categorization.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Regular Hours (Mon-Thu)
rule_text: The regular work week will consist of four (4) nine (9) hour straight time days Monday to Thursday in the second week.
summary: In the second week of a 9/80 schedule, the regular workday from Monday to Thursday is 9 hours at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> MAX(9_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard straight-time hours for specific days within the second week of the 9/80 schedule, forming a basis for time categorization.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Friday Day Off
rule_text: Friday is a day off.
summary: On a 9/80 schedule, the Friday of the second week is a scheduled day off.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> APPLY(EDO)
reasoning: This rule establishes a scheduled day off (EDO) within the work schedule, which dictates how time worked on that day is treated (as overtime from the first hour).

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime (Mon-Thu, 1.5x)
rule_text: Week 1 Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first three (3) hours worked before or after the regular nine (9) hour days.
summary: In week 1 of a 9/80 schedule, on Monday through Thursday, the first 3 hours of overtime are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_overtime_hours > 0 AND daily_overtime_hours <= 3 -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines the first tier of overtime pay for specific days within the 9/80 schedule, directly addressing the categorization and payment of worked hours.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime (Mon-Thu, 2.0x)
rule_text: Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In week 1 of a 9/80 schedule, on Monday through Thursday, any overtime hours worked beyond the first 3 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_overtime_hours > 3 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime pay that follows the first, establishing a clear threshold for when hours transition to double time, which is a key aspect of labor time calculation.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime (Friday, 1.5x)
rule_text: Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first (4) hours worked before or after the regular eight (8) hour days.
summary: In week 1 of a 9/80 schedule, on Friday, the first 4 hours of overtime are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_overtime_hours > 0 AND daily_overtime_hours <= 4 -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies the first overtime tier for a particular day (Friday) within the schedule, directly governing how worked hours are categorized and paid.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime (Friday, 2.0x)
rule_text: Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In week 1 of a 9/80 schedule, on Friday, any overtime hours worked beyond the first 4 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 1 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_overtime_hours > 4 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime pay for Fridays in week 1, establishing the threshold for double time, a key calculation for labor hours.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Overtime (Mon-Thu, 1.5x)
rule_text: Week 2 Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first three (3) hours worked before or after the regular nine (9) hour days.
summary: In week 2 of a 9/80 schedule, on Monday through Thursday, the first 3 hours of overtime are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_overtime_hours > 0 AND daily_overtime_hours <= 3 -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule sets the first overtime tier for the second week of the schedule, directly related to how worked hours are calculated and paid.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Overtime (Mon-Thu, 2.0x)
rule_text: Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In week 2 of a 9/80 schedule, on Monday through Thursday, any overtime hours worked beyond the first 3 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_overtime_hours > 3 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule specifies the second overtime tier for the second week, establishing the threshold for double time, which is fundamental to labor time calculation.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Earned Friday Off Overtime (1.5x)
rule_text: Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first twelve (12) hours worked on the earned Friday off.
summary: On the scheduled Friday off in a 9/80 schedule, the first 12 hours worked are paid at 1.5 times the straight rate.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_hours > 0 AND daily_hours <= 12 -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for work on a scheduled day off, which is a specific rule for categorizing and paying labor hours that would otherwise be non-working time.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Earned Friday Off Overtime (2.0x)
rule_text: Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: On the scheduled Friday off in a 9/80 schedule, any hours worked beyond the first 12 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND week_number (Unsupported) == 2 AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_hours > 12 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of pay for work on a scheduled day off, establishing the threshold for double time, a critical component of labor time categorization.

name: Sunday and Statutory Holiday Pay
rule_text: Double-time will be paid on Sundays and Statutory Holidays for all hours worked
summary: All hours worked on Sundays or Statutory Holidays are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) AND daily_hours > 0 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule provides a premium pay rate for specific days (Sundays and holidays), which is a key rule for categorizing and calculating pay for worked time.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement Threshold
rule_text: It is understood that those required to work more than ten (10) hours on this shift are entitled to an overtime meal and break pursuant to the overtime meal articles in the agreement.
summary: Employees on this shift who work more than 10 hours are entitled to an overtime meal and break as defined elsewhere in the agreement.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '9/80' AND daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(overtime_meal_and_break)
reasoning: This rule establishes the hourly threshold that triggers an entitlement to a meal allowance and break, which falls directly under the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: IOL Strathcona Maintenance Schedule
rule_text: Those employees working long-term maintenance at the Imperial Oil Strathcona site will work eight and sixth tenths (8.6) hours at straight time Monday to Friday.
summary: At the Imperial Oil Strathcona site, employees engaged in long-term maintenance work a schedule of 8.6 hours per day, Monday through Friday, at the straight time rate. An additional 0.6 hours is worked daily to compensate for 16 scheduled Earned Days Off (EDOs).
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'IOL_STRATHCONA' AND work_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_MAINTENANCE' -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('5x8.6_mon_fri') AND PAY(ST) FOR daily_hours <= 8.6
reasoning: This rule defines the standard work schedule, including days, hours per day, and the straight time pay rate, which are fundamental to labor time calculation.

name: IOL Strathcona Daily Overtime Trigger
rule_text: All additional hours after the eight and sixth tenths (8.6) will be performed at the regular overtime provisions as indicated in the Maintenance Agreement.
summary: For employees on the IOL Strathcona maintenance schedule, any hours worked beyond 8.6 in a single day are considered overtime and paid according to the main agreement's overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8.6_mon_fri' AND daily_hours > 8.6 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the daily threshold at which straight time ends and overtime begins, a core component of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime Meal Break Entitlement
rule_text: It is understood that those required to work more than ten (10) hours on this shift are entitled to an overtime meal break at the ten hour mark (10) pursuant to the overtime meal articles in this agreement.
summary: An employee who works more than 10 hours in a shift is entitled to an overtime meal break at the 10-hour mark.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_BREAK) AT(10_hours)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to a meal break based on a specific threshold of hours worked, which is the definition of a meal allowance rule.

name: Work on Scheduled EDOs
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's will be paid at double (2x).
summary: Any work performed on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) must be paid at double the employee's regular rate.
logical_representation: IF is_edo_day (llm) == true -> PAY(2.0x)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific pay rate (double time) for work on a particular type of day (an EDO), directly related to how labor time is categorized and compensated.

name: Agreement Validity Period
rule_text: Effective: June 1, 2025 to December 31, 2028, including any statutory bridging.
summary: This agreement is effective from June 1, 2025, to December 31, 2028.
logical_representation: APPLY_RULES_WHEN date >= validity_start_date AND date <= validity_end_date
reasoning: This rule defines the date range for which all other labor rules in the agreement are valid, making it a foundational element of worked time calculation.

name: Compressed Work Week Establishment (>14 days)
rule_text: A "Compressed Work Week" system may be established when it is intended to operate the system in excess of fourteen (14) calendar days. The system may be arranged to cover continuous plant operation for seven (7) days per week.
summary: A compressed work week (CWW) schedule can be set up if it's planned to run for more than 14 calendar days, potentially covering continuous 7-day operations.
logical_representation: IF schedule_duration_days (llm) > 14 -> ALLOW(schedule_type='CWW')
reasoning: This rule sets the conditions for defining and establishing a specific type of work schedule (Compressed Work Week), which directly impacts how time is categorized and paid.

name: Compressed Work Week Establishment (40-hour average)
rule_text: The fourteen (14) calendar day requirement does not apply to those compressed work week schedules that average forty (40) hours per week, Monday to Friday. In this case, the schedule must be established for a minimum of one (1) week timeframe, Monday to Friday.
summary: For compressed work week schedules that average 40 hours per week (Monday to Friday), the schedule only needs to be established for a minimum of one week, not more than 14 days.
logical_representation: IF weekly_hours == 40 AND schedule_duration_days (llm) >= 5 -> ALLOW(schedule_type='CWW')
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative condition for establishing a Compressed Work Week schedule, which is a fundamental aspect of defining how worked time is structured and paid.

name: CWW Pay Reversion Penalty
rule_text: In the event that the fourteen (14) day conditions are not met, pay conditions will be adjusted to pay eight (8) hours per day Monday through Friday at the straight time hourly rate, plus applicable shift premium, and all hours worked after the eight (8) hours per day, Monday through Friday and all hours worked on Saturday and Sunday at the applicable overtime rates.
summary: If a compressed work week schedule does not last for its required minimum duration (e.g., 14 days), all time worked will be recalculated. Pay reverts to a standard 5x8 schedule, with straight time for the first 8 hours per day (Mon-Fri) and overtime for any hours beyond that and on weekends.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'CWW' AND schedule_duration_days (llm) < 14 -> REVERT_PAY_RULES('5x8')
reasoning: This rule defines a penalty for failing to meet schedule duration requirements, which involves re-categorizing all worked hours according to a different pay structure. This is a core function of labor time processing.

name: CWW Standard Day Length
rule_text: The standard work day shall be up to twelve (12) hours of continuous employment including lunch breaks except those breaks provided for in Article 1.506.
summary: On a compressed work week, the standard workday can be up to 12 continuous hours, which includes lunch breaks (unless it's an unpaid lunch on a 10-hour shift).
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'CWW' -> daily_hours <= 12
reasoning: This rule defines the standard length of a workday under a specific schedule type, which is a foundational parameter for calculating straight time and overtime hours.

name: CWW Overtime Trigger
rule_text: All overtime worked in excess of a regularly scheduled twelve (12), ten (10) or eight (8) hour shift and all hours worked on regularly scheduled days off shall be paid at the applicable overtime provisions in accordance with the established Compressed Work Week rates.
summary: On a compressed work week, overtime is paid for any hours worked beyond the regular scheduled shift (8, 10, or 12 hours) and for all hours worked on scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'CWW' AND (daily_hours > scheduled_daily_hours (llm) OR is_scheduled_day_off (llm) == true) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the triggers for overtime calculation on compressed work week schedules, making it a core rule for categorizing worked hours.

name: EDO Overtime, 12-Hour Shift
rule_text: On the twelve (12) hour day, all Earned Days Off (EDO's) will be compensated as follows: The first three (3) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next six (6) hours worked at time and one half (1½x) The last three (3) hours worked at double-time (2x).
summary: When working on an Earned Day Off (EDO) for a 12-hour shift schedule, the pay is tiered: the first 3 hours are at double time, the next 6 hours are at time-and-a-half, and the final 3 hours are at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND scheduled_daily_hours (llm) == 12 -> PAY(daily_hours <= 3 at 2.0x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 3 AND daily_hours <= 9 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 9 AND daily_hours <= 12 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule specifies a complex, tiered overtime structure for a particular scenario (working on an EDO), which is a detailed instruction on how to categorize and rate worked hours.

name: EDO Overtime, 10-Hour Shift
rule_text: On the ten (10) hour day, all EDO's will be compensated as follows: The first two and one half (2 ½) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next five (5) hours worked at time and one half (1 ½x) The last two and one half (2 ½) hours worked at double-time (2x)
summary: When working on an Earned Day Off (EDO) for a 10-hour shift schedule, the pay is tiered: the first 2.5 hours are at double time, the next 5 hours are at time-and-a-half, and the final 2.5 hours are at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND scheduled_daily_hours (llm) == 10 -> PAY(daily_hours <= 2.5 at 2.0x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 2.5 AND daily_hours <= 7.5 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 7.5 AND daily_hours <= 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule specifies a complex, tiered overtime structure for a particular scenario (working on an EDO), which is a detailed instruction on how to categorize and rate worked hours.

name: EDO Overtime, 8-Hour Shift
rule_text: On the eight (8) hour day, all EDO's will be compensated as follows: The first two (2) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next four (4) hours worked at time and one half (1 ½x) The last two (2) hours at double-time (2x)
summary: When working on an Earned Day Off (EDO) for an 8-hour shift schedule, the pay is tiered: the first 2 hours are at double time, the next 4 hours are at time-and-a-half, and the final 2 hours are at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_earned_day_off (llm) == true AND scheduled_daily_hours (llm) == 8 -> PAY(daily_hours <= 2 at 2.0x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 2 AND daily_hours <= 6 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 6 AND daily_hours <= 8 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule specifies a complex, tiered overtime structure for a particular scenario (working on an EDO), which is a detailed instruction on how to categorize and rate worked hours.

name: Statutory Holiday Work Pay
rule_text: All hours worked on Statutory Holidays will be paid at double-time (2x) in accordance with Compressed Work Week rates.
summary: All hours worked on a statutory holiday are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for work on a specific type of day (statutory holiday), which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing and paying for worked time.

name: CWW Night Shift Premium
rule_text: The shift premium on all compressed work week night shifts will be three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) per hour for all straight time hours worked on shift.
summary: A premium of $3.50 per hour is paid for all straight time hours worked on a compressed work week night shift.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'CWW' AND shift_type == 'NIGHT' -> PREMIUM($3.50) FOR ST_HOURS
reasoning: This rule establishes a monetary premium based on the time of day worked (night shift), which is a core component of calculating labor costs for worked time.

name: Unpaid Lunch on 10-Hour Shifts
rule_text: When working ten (10) hours with two (2) fifteen (15) minute paid breaks and a half (1/2) hour lunch, the midday lunch period of one-half (1/2) hour on workdays of ten (10) hours or less between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m. will be unpaid.
summary: On a 10-hour day shift (between 7:30 am and 7:30 pm), the 30-minute midday lunch break is unpaid. The two 15-minute breaks are paid.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours <= 10 AND shift_type == 'DAY' AND break_type (llm) == 'LUNCH' -> PAY(break_duration_minutes (llm) == 30 at 0.0x)
reasoning: This rule defines whether a specific period of time within a workday (a lunch break) is paid or unpaid, directly impacting the calculation of total paid hours.

name: Paid Breaks on 12-Hour Shifts
rule_text: On twelve (12) hour shifts when working in conjunction with the Client's personnel the breaks provided will be the same as those scheduled for the Client working the same compressed work week schedule in the area. Under no circumstances will the employee be denied their required breaks. In all other instances there shall be three (3) half hour (1/2) paid breaks per twelve (12) hour shifts.
summary: On a 12-hour shift, employees receive three paid 30-minute breaks. If working alongside client personnel, they will follow the client's break schedule instead.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours == 12 -> PAY(break_duration_minutes (llm) == 30 at 1.0x) FOR 3 BREAKS
reasoning: This rule determines that breaks taken during a 12-hour shift are paid, which is a key factor in calculating the total compensable hours for the day.

name: Shift Change Notice Penalty
rule_text: An employee will be given twenty-four (24) hours advance notice prior to the start of their new shift and if not then they shall be paid their first shift at time and one-half (1 ½x).
summary: If an employee is not given at least 24 hours' notice before a shift change, their entire first shift on the new schedule must be paid at time-and-a-half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice_hours (llm) < 24 -> PREMIUM(1.5) FOR first_shift
reasoning: This rule imposes a premium pay rate on worked hours as a penalty for insufficient notice, directly altering the calculation of labor cost for that time.

name: Pay for Lost Time on CWW Shift Change
rule_text: If an employee loses time on their initial Compressed Work Week schedule due to having their Compressed Work Week schedule changed to a new Compressed Work Week schedule, they shall be paid for those hours they would have worked on their initial schedule up to the start of their new schedule. In no case will missed hours be paid if the employee works forty (40) or more straight time hours in the calendar week. If less than forty (40) hours is worked in the calendar week, missed hours on the initial schedule will be paid but only to the extent that straight time hours on the new schedule in the calendar week plus hours worked on the old schedule in the calendar week plus missed hours on the initial schedule does not exceed forty (40).
summary: If a change between CWW schedules causes an employee to lose scheduled work hours, they will be paid for those lost hours, but only up to a maximum of 40 total straight-time hours for that week (including hours already worked and paid lost hours).
logical_representation: IF lost_hours_due_to_shift_change (llm) > 0 AND weekly_hours < 40 -> PAY(MIN(lost_hours_due_to_shift_change (llm), 40 - weekly_hours)) AT ST
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism for compensating employees for scheduled time they were unable to work due to an employer's action, ensuring a minimum weekly pay. This is a form of guaranteed time and falls under labor worked time.

name: EDO Handling on Shift Transfer
rule_text: When an employee is transferred to a different shift schedule all scheduled days off which have been earned must be given to the employee prior to the start of their new schedule. If earned days off are worked they shall be considered overtime and paid the applicable overtime rate.
summary: When an employee is transferred to a new shift, any Earned Days Off (EDOs) they have accrued must be taken before the new schedule starts. If the employee is required to work on these EDOs, the time must be paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TRANSFER' AND is_earned_day_off (llm) == true -> PAY(OT) OR PROVIDE(time_off)
reasoning: This rule dictates how a specific type of time off (EDO) is treated during a change in work status. It mandates that this time is either taken as leave or paid out at a premium rate, both of which are core labor time calculations.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Weekday
rule_text: Monday: 8 hours Straight Time, Up to 2 hours TimeandOneHalf (1.5x), After 10 hours DoubleTime (2x)
summary: On a 5x8 schedule (Monday-Friday), the first 8 hours are paid at straight time, the next 2 hours (hours 9 and 10) are at time-and-a-half, and any hours worked beyond 10 are at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(daily_hours <= 8 at ST) AND PAY(daily_hours > 8 AND daily_hours <= 10 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule provides a clear, tiered structure for calculating daily overtime for a standard work schedule, which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked hours.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Saturday/Sunday/Stat Holiday
rule_text:
Saturday: All hours DoubleTime (2x)
Sunday: All hours DoubleTime (2x)
Stat Holiday: All hours DoubleTime (2x)
summary: On a 5x8 schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for specific days of the week and holidays on a standard schedule, which is a core component of processing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Regular Day
rule_text: Monday-Thursday: 10 hours Straight Time, After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a regular workday (Mon-Thu) are paid at straight time, and any hours beyond 10 are at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> PAY(daily_hours <= 10 at ST) AND PAY(daily_hours > 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule defines the daily overtime threshold and rate for a specific compressed work week schedule, a key function in categorizing worked hours.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Friday
rule_text: Friday: Up to 10 hours Time and One Half (1.5x), After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, all hours worked on a Friday (a scheduled day off) are paid as overtime: the first 10 hours at time-and-a-half, and any hours beyond 10 at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> PAY(daily_hours <= 10 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule provides a tiered overtime structure for working on a scheduled day off within a specific schedule, which is a core rule for labor time calculation.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Sat/Sun/Stat
rule_text:
Saturday: All hours Double Time (2x)
Sunday: All hours Double Time (2x)
Stat Holiday: All hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for specific days of the week and holidays on a compressed work week schedule, a core component of processing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Regular Day
rule_text: Tuesday-Friday: 10 hours Straight Time, After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a regular workday (Tue-Fri) are paid at straight time, and any hours beyond 10 are at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week IN ['TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(daily_hours <= 10 at ST) AND PAY(daily_hours > 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule defines the daily overtime threshold and rate for a specific compressed work week schedule, a key function in categorizing worked hours.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Monday
rule_text: Monday: Up to 10 hours Time and One Half (1.5x), After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, all hours worked on a Monday (a scheduled day off) are paid as overtime: the first 10 hours at time-and-a-half, and any hours beyond 10 at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week == 'MON' -> PAY(daily_hours <= 10 at 1.5x) AND PAY(daily_hours > 10 at 2.0x)
reasoning: This rule provides a tiered overtime structure for working on a scheduled day off within a specific schedule, which is a core rule for labor time calculation.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Sat/Sun/Stat
rule_text:
Saturday: All hours Double Time (2x)
Sunday: All hours Double Time (2x)
Stat Holiday: All hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for specific days of the week and holidays on a compressed work week schedule, a core component of processing worked time.

name: Bereavement Pay
