rule_text: Welders successfully completing such tests shall receive a regular day's pay at straight time rates for any working day lost, due to transportation delays, or when test pieces must be sent to an outside agency for assessment, except when transportation delays are beyond the control of the Employer.
summary: A welder who passes a test will receive a full day's pay for any workday lost while waiting for transportation or external test assessment, unless the transport delay was beyond the employer's control.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND test_result (Unsupported) == 'PASS' AND (is_transportation_delay (llm) == true OR is_waiting_for_assessment (llm) == true) AND is_delay_employer_controlled (llm) != false -> PAY(1_DAY_ST)
reasoning: This rule mandates pay for non-productive waiting time under specific conditions, classifying it as a rule for compensating labor time.

name: Forfeiture of Pay and Allowances for Failure to Report to Work
rule_text: Welders, upon successfully completing such tests, who fail to report for work, or fail to commence work when directed, will not be eligible for daily subsistence, travel allowance, transportation, accommodation, waiting, and/or testing time pay.
summary: Welders who pass a test but then fail to report to work when directed lose their eligibility for all related payments and allowances, including subsistence, travel, accommodation, and pay for waiting or testing time.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND test_result (Unsupported) == 'PASS' AND work_start_status (Unsupported) == 'FAILED_TO_START' -> FORFEIT(ALL_TEST_RELATED_PAY_AND_ALLOWANCES)
reasoning: This rule primarily concerns the forfeiture of various allowances (subsistence, travel, accommodation), placing it under LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE, but also affects pay for time (waiting, testing), justifying a secondary topic.

name: Welding Test Incentive Fee
rule_text:
A welder (Journeyman or Apprentice) who is required by the Employer or the Employer's client to perform on any Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW) test or Gas Metal Arc Welding (GMAW) test or Flux-Core Arc Welding (FCAW) test for pressure welding will be paid a testing fee of one hundred  and  seventy-five  ($175.00)  dollars  effective  May  1,  2013  providing  they  meet  the following criteria:
- (a) The welder must successfully pass the relevant test.
- (b) The welder remains on the project a minimum of thirty (30) days or until lay off, whichever occurs first
- (c) The welder cannot refuse to utilize the tested procedure while employed on the project.

Providing these criteria are met, the welder incentive test fee will be paid after the thirty days of employment or upon lay off, whichever occurs first.
summary: A Journeyman or Apprentice welder will receive a $175 incentive fee for taking a GTAW, GMAW, or FCAW pressure test if they pass, remain on the project for 30 days (or until layoff), and don't refuse to use the procedure. The fee is paid after 30 days or at layoff, whichever is first.
logical_representation: IF (employee_class IN ['JOURNEYMAN', 'APPRENTICE']) AND position_classification == 'WELDER' AND (welding_process (llm) IN ['GTAW', 'GMAW', 'FCAW']) AND test_result (Unsupported) == 'PASS' AND (days_on_project (llm) >= 30 OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF') AND refused_procedure (llm) == false AND validity_start_date >= '2013-05-01' -> PAY(INCENTIVE_FEE, $175.00)
reasoning: This rule outlines a specific fee, a form of compensation, tied directly to a work-related activity and subsequent performance conditions. This falls under the broader category of payment for labor time and skills.

name: Alloy Welder Premium (Dispatch Requirement)
rule_text: Welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of $3.25 per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: Welders who were required to have an alloy welding certificate for their job assignment will be paid an extra $3.25 for each hour worked.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND is_dispatched_with_cert (llm) == true -> PREMIUM($3.25)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific hourly premium based on a pre-existing qualification, directly affecting the rate of pay for worked time.

name: Alloy Welder Premium (On-Site Reclassification)
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to be certified by the employer and is requested to perform alloy welding, the worker will be re-classified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium for all hours worked during the applicable work cycle.
summary: If a welder not originally hired as an alloy welder is asked to perform alloy work, they are reclassified and paid the alloy premium for all hours in that work rotation.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND is_reclassified (llm) == true -> PREMIUM($3.25_FOR_ALL_HOURS_IN_WORK_CYCLE)
reasoning: This rule dictates the application of a premium pay rate based on a change in work assignment, which is a core component of calculating labor compensation.

name: Alloy Welder Premium Lock-in on 3rd Reclassification
rule_text: The worker may only be reclassified to a maximum of 2 times in a calendar year, if the worker is reclassified a 3rd time within the calendar year the worker is entitled to the premium for all hours worked from the date of the employee being reclassified a 3rd time, until the worker is laid off or terminated.
summary: A worker can be temporarily reclassified as an alloy welder twice a year. If they are reclassified a third time in the same year, they will permanently receive the alloy premium for all hours worked until they are laid off or terminated.
logical_representation: IF reclassification_count_in_year (llm) == 3 -> PREMIUM($3.25_FOR_ALL_HOURS_UNTIL_TERMINATION_OR_LAYOFF)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition that triggers a long-term, continuous premium payment, directly impacting the calculation of the rate for worked hours.

name: Apprentice Pay Rate with Provisional 'C' Ticket
rule_text: When an apprentice in the employ of an employer acquires a Provisional 'C' Welders ticket that allows them to perform pressure welds for that employer that apprentice will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate while engaged in that work for their employer.
summary: An apprentice who obtains a Provisional 'C' Welder's ticket will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate for any pressure welding work they perform.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'APPRENTICE' AND has_provisional_c_ticket (llm) == true AND activity_type (Unsupported) == 'PRESSURE_WELDING' -> PAY_RATE('Journeyman Welder without CWB')
reasoning: This rule specifies a change in the base pay rate based on the employee's class and a specific certification, which is a fundamental rule of worked time compensation.

name: Out-of-Jurisdiction Journeyman Pay Rate with Provisional 'C' Ticket
rule_text: A journeyman pressure welder from another jurisdiction outside of Alberta who is working under a Provisional 'C' Welders ticket will be paid at the UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder rate.
summary: A journeyman pressure welder from outside Alberta working with a Provisional 'C' Welder's ticket must be paid at the 'UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder' rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'JOURNEYMAN' AND position_classification == 'PRESSURE_WELDER' AND jurisdiction (Unsupported) != 'ALBERTA' AND has_provisional_c_ticket (llm) == true -> PAY_RATE('UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder')
reasoning: This rule defines the specific pay rate for an employee based on their class, jurisdiction, and certification, directly governing how their worked time is paid.

name: Recognized Holiday Work Pay Rate
rule_text: All work performed on the following recognized holidays, and any general holiday declared by the level of government with jurisdiction, either the Federal or Provincial, shall be paid for at the rate of double time, plus any applicable shift differential, as follows:
summary: Work performed on a recognized holiday, or any holiday declared by Federal or Provincial governments, is paid at double the regular rate (2.0x), plus any applicable shift differential.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> PREMIUM(2.0) AND PREMIUM(shift_differential (llm))
reasoning: The rule defines a premium pay rate (double time) for hours worked on a specific type of day (a statutory holiday), which is a core concept of categorizing worked time for payment.

name: List of Recognized Holidays
rule_text:
| New Years Day (Jan 1)   | Labour Day (September)             |
|-------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Family Day (February)   | Nat. Day for Truth &Rec. (Sept 30) |
| Good Friday (April)     | Thanksgiving Day (October)         |
| Victoria Day (Monday)   | Remembrance Day (Nov 11)           |
| Canada Day (July1)      | Christmas Day (Dec 25)             |
| Heritage Day (August)   | Boxing Day (Dec 26)                |
summary: The contract specifies twelve holidays: New Year's Day, Family Day, Good Friday, Victoria Day, Canada Day, Heritage Day, Labour Day, National Day for Truth & Reconciliation, Thanksgiving Day, Remembrance Day, Christmas Day, and Boxing Day.
logical_representation: DEFINE statutory_holiday_list = ['NEW_YEARS_DAY', 'FAMILY_DAY', 'GOOD_FRIDAY', 'VICTORIA_DAY', 'CANADA_DAY', 'HERITAGE_DAY', 'LABOUR_DAY', 'NATIONAL_DAY_TRUTH_REC', 'THANKSGIVING_DAY', 'REMEMBRANCE_DAY', 'CHRISTMAS_DAY', 'BOXING_DAY']
reasoning: This rule provides the definitive list of days considered statutory holidays, which is required to apply premium pay rules. It is a foundational element of time categorization.

name: Holiday Observance Date
rule_text: Each of the general holidays listed in clause 14.01 shall be observed on the calendar date on which it occurs, premiums will apply for hours worked
summary: Recognized holidays are to be observed on their actual calendar date, and any hours worked on that date are subject to premium pay.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(is_stat_holiday_observance = calendar_date (llm))
reasoning: This rule specifies how to determine the exact day on which holiday pay rules apply, which is essential for correctly categorizing worked time.

name: Labour Day Work Prohibition
rule_text: No work shall be performed on Labour Day, except for the preservation of life or imminent danger to property.
summary: Work is prohibited on Labour Day, with exceptions only for emergencies to preserve life or prevent imminent danger to property.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == 'LABOUR_DAY' -> CONSTRAINT(NO_WORK_ALLOWED_UNLESS_EMERGENCY)
reasoning: This rule places a specific constraint on when work can be performed, which is a fundamental rule governing worked time.

name: Statutory Holiday Pay (In Lieu)
rule_text: In lieu of pay for the above recognized holidays the Employer shall pay an additional 4% to the Employee's total hourly earnings each week, including overtime hours and premium time hours.
summary: Instead of receiving pay for each individual holiday, employees receive an additional 4% of their total weekly hourly earnings (including overtime and premium hours) on each paycheck.
logical_representation: PAY(total_weekly_earnings (llm) * 0.04) AS stat_holiday_pay (llm)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific calculation for holiday pay, which is a component of the overall compensation for labor time.

name: Vacation Pay Calculation and Payout
rule_text: Employees annual Vacation Pay shall be 6% of the Employee's total hourly earnings. Such total hourly earnings shall be deemed to include straight time hours, overtime hours, premium time hours and shall be paid each pay period with the Employee's regular pay.
summary: Employees receive vacation pay calculated at 6% of their total hourly earnings, which includes straight time, overtime, and premium hours. This amount is paid out with their regular wages each pay period.
logical_representation: PAY(total_hourly_earnings (llm) * 0.06) AS vacation_pay (llm) PER pay_period (llm)
reasoning: This rule outlines the calculation and payout frequency for vacation pay, which is directly tied to hours worked and earnings, making it a rule about compensation for labor time.

name: VHP/SHP Payout Options (Calgary 496)
summary: For commercial or institutional work within the Calgary 496 jurisdiction, there are specific, defined options for when Vacation and Holiday Pay (VHP/SHP) can be paid out: with each paycheck, at vacation time, at year-end, or upon termination.
logical_representation: IF jurisdiction (Unsupported) == 'CALGARY_496' AND project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] -> DEFINE valid_payout_options (llm) = ['PER_PAYCHECK', 'ON_VACATION', 'YEAR_END', 'ON_TERMINATION']
reasoning: This rule specifies the valid payout schedules for vacation and holiday pay under specific conditions, which is part of administering compensation for labor time.

name: VHP/SHP Payout Decision Mechanism (Calgary 496)
rule_text: Whether the Employees receive the above noted holiday and vacation pay each pay period, or whether the vacation and holiday pay are to be retained by the Employer and paid to each Employee at the time of the Employee's vacation or on the last pay day in the calendar year or upon termination of the Employee's employment (whichever occurs first), shall be determined by a majority vote of the Employees of that Employer.
summary: For applicable work in the Calgary 496 jurisdiction, the choice of how vacation and holiday pay is paid out (either per paycheck or retained for later payout) is determined by a majority vote of the employees.
logical_representation: IF jurisdiction (Unsupported) == 'CALGARY_496' -> DECISION(payout_method_for_vhp_shp (llm), 'EMPLOYEE_MAJORITY_VOTE')
reasoning: This rule establishes the procedure for selecting a payout method for earnings derived from labor time, which is an administrative rule for compensation.

name: Standard Unpaid Lunch Break
rule_text: The lunch break will consist of a one-half hour unpaid break taken approximately mid-way during the regular workday.
summary: Employees are entitled to a 30-minute unpaid lunch break, taken around the middle of their regular workday.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(LUNCH_BREAK_DURATION == 30_MINUTES) AND CONSTRAINT(LUNCH_BREAK_IS_UNPAID)
reasoning: This rule defines the duration and pay status of a standard break within the workday, which is a core component of how worked time is structured.

name: Delayed Lunch Break Penalty
rule_text: If the lunch break is delayed such that it starts more than one-half hour after the completion of the normal lunch break, the Employee will be paid an additional one-half hour at their applicable straight time rate for the one-half hour lunch break.
summary: If an employee's lunch break starts more than 30 minutes after its normally scheduled end time, they will be paid for their 30-minute lunch break at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF lunch_break_delay_minutes (llm) > 30 -> PAY(0.5_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule mandates a specific payment (0.5 hours at ST) when a condition related to the timing of a work break is met. This directly affects labor cost and is a worked time rule.

name: Standard Coffee Breaks
rule_text: All Employees covered by this agreement shall be permitted ten (10) minutes in the first half and ten (10) minutes in the second half of a shift for a coffee break on the job during regular working hours.
summary: Employees are entitled to two 10-minute paid coffee breaks during regular working hours, one in the first half and one in the second half of their shift.
logical_representation: PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(10_minutes, 'first_half_shift')) AND PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(10_minutes, 'second_half_shift'))
reasoning: This rule defines paid breaks, which are an integral part of calculating total paid time for a shift.

name: Overtime Coffee Breaks
rule_text: If extended overtime is required, additional coffee breaks shall be permitted during such overtime after each two (2) hours following each overtime meal break.
summary: During extended overtime, employees are entitled to additional paid coffee breaks every two hours after an overtime meal break.
logical_representation: IF daily_overtime_hours > 0 -> PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK EVERY 2_HOURS AFTER event(overtime_meal_break))
reasoning: This rule specifies the entitlement to paid breaks during overtime periods, which is a direct component of worked time rules.

name: Industrial Compressed Work Week Breaks
rule_text: However, for INDUSTRIAL WORK ONLY and on a compressed work week scheduled pursuant to Article 17.00, Employees shall be permitted a break of fifteen (15) minutes in the first half and fifteen (15) minutes in the second half of such shifts.
summary: For employees on a compressed work week schedule for Industrial work, the two paid coffee breaks are extended to 15 minutes each.
logical_representation: IF work_type (llm) == 'INDUSTRIAL' AND schedule_type == 'COMPRESSED' -> PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(15_minutes, 'first_half_shift')) AND PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(15_minutes, 'second_half_shift'))
reasoning: This rule modifies the standard break duration based on the work type and schedule, altering the structure of the paid workday.

name: 10-Hour Shift Paid Breaks Option
rule_text: When ten (10) hour shifts are worked, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two breaks of one half (½) hour each, paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On 10-hour shifts, the employer has the option to replace the standard lunch and coffee breaks with two 30-minute paid breaks, spaced evenly throughout the shift.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours == 10 -> OPTION(EMPLOYER, PROVIDE(2 * PAID_BREAK(30_minutes)) IN_LIEU_OF(STANDARD_LUNCH_AND_COFFEE_BREAKS))
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative break structure for a specific shift length (10 hours), defining them as paid time, which directly impacts labor time calculation.

name: Missed Break Penalty (General)
rule_text: In the event an employee is not able to take a break, the employee shall be paid at applicable overtime rates for the missed break.
summary: If an employee cannot take their scheduled break, they must be paid for the duration of the missed break at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF break_missed (llm) == true -> PAY(missed_break_duration AT APPLICABLE_OT_RATE)
reasoning: This rule creates a direct payment obligation at a premium rate when a break entitlement is not fulfilled. This is a rule for calculating paid time.

name: Missed Break Penalty (Straight Time Context)
rule_text: When the hour before and the hour following the missed break are at straight tine, time and one half (1 ½ x) shall be paid for the missed break.
summary: If an employee misses a break during a period when they are being paid straight time, the missed break time must be paid at time and a half (1.5x).
logical_representation: IF break_missed (llm) == true AND surrounding_hours_pay_rate (llm) == 'ST' -> PAY(missed_break_duration AT 1.5x)
reasoning: This rule specifies the exact premium (1.5x) for a missed break under specific conditions (surrounding hours are ST), making it a precise labor cost calculation rule.

name: 10-Hour Paid Break Option Constraint
rule_text: This option shall not be applicable to compressed work weeks for which workdays are regularly scheduled in excess of ten (10) hours.
summary: The option to provide two 30-minute paid breaks instead of standard breaks is not available for compressed work week schedules where shifts are regularly longer than 10 hours.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'COMPRESSED' AND daily_hours > 10 -> CONSTRAINT(OPTION_FOR_2x30_PAID_BREAKS_IS_INAPPLICABLE)
reasoning: This rule places a constraint on a specific break scheduling option based on the schedule type and shift length, thus defining the structure of the workday.

name: Pay for Waiting Time on Negative POCT Result (Sample Provided)
rule_text: If an employer requests a worker to participate in a POCT risk assessment pursuant to 4.8.5 of the Canadian Model , and the worker provides the urine sample, and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall be paid for any time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result, except for such discipline that was justified by the worker's conduct in respect to the incident or reasons for the test request.
summary: If an employee provides a sample for a Point of Collection Test (POCT) and the result is negative, they will be paid for the time they were waiting for the result that they would have otherwise been working. This pay can be withheld if discipline was warranted for the employee's conduct related to the incident that triggered the test.
logical_representation: IF test (Unsupported) == 'POCT' AND sample_provided (llm) == true AND test_result (Unsupported) == 'NEGATIVE' AND discipline_warranted (llm) == false -> PAY(waiting_time_as_worked_time)
reasoning: This rule dictates when non-productive waiting time becomes compensable, making it a rule about calculating paid hours.

name: No Pay for Waiting Time on POCT Result (Sample Declined)
rule_text: If the worker declines to provide the sample for the POCT risk assessment and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall not be entitled to any pay for time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result.
summary: If an employee declines to provide an initial sample for a Point of Collection Test (POCT), they will not be paid for any time spent waiting for the subsequent laboratory test result, even if it comes back negative.
logical_representation: IF test (Unsupported) == 'POCT' AND sample_provided (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(PAY_FOR_WAITING_TIME)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines a scenario where time is not compensable, directly impacting the calculation of total paid hours.

name: Normal Workday Definition
rule_text: The maximum of eight (8) hours shall constitute a normal day's work beginning at 8:00 AM and ending by 5:00 PM (except when one-half (½) hour lunch is taken in which case the normal day will end at 4:30 PM).
summary: A normal workday is defined as a maximum of 8 hours, typically starting at 8:00 AM and ending at 5:00 PM, or 4:30 PM if a half-hour lunch is taken.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> DEFINE(NORMAL_DAY_HOURS=8)
reasoning: This rule establishes the standard number of hours in a workday, which is foundational for determining when straight time ends and overtime begins. It directly relates to the categorization of worked time.

name: Normal Work Week Definition
rule_text: The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 8:00 AM and ending Friday at 5:00 PM.
summary: A normal work week is defined as a maximum of 40 hours, running from Monday at 8:00 AM to Friday at 5:00 PM.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> DEFINE(NORMAL_WEEK_HOURS=40 AND DAYS='MON,TUE,WED,THU,FRI')
reasoning: This rule sets the weekly threshold for straight time hours and defines the days of the standard work week, which is essential for overtime calculations.

name: No Guarantee of Hours
rule_text: The above schedule is intended to represent a  normal workday or work week and is not to be construed as a guarantee of hours of work per day or per week or with respect to days in a week.
summary: The defined normal workday and work week schedules are not a guarantee of a specific amount of work hours or days.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(SCHEDULE_IS_NOT_A_GUARANTEE_OF_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule is a condition related to the hours of work, clarifying that the schedule definition does not create an entitlement to a minimum number of hours. It constrains the application of schedule rules.

name: Employer Start/Quit Time Variation
rule_text: The Employer may vary the start/quit times by changing the scheduled starting time up to one hour at their option.
summary: The employer has the option to change the scheduled start and end times by up to one hour.
logical_representation: IF shift_start_time_change_hours (llm) <= 1 -> ALLOW(EMPLOYER_DISCRETION)
reasoning: This rule directly impacts the definition of the standard workday by allowing for schedule adjustments, which affects how daily hours are tracked and categorized.

name: Start/Quit Time Variation Over One Hour
rule_text: Variances beyond one (1) hour shall be agreed mutually by the Employer and the Business Representative of the Union and the consent to variance will not be unreasonably withheld.
summary: Any changes to start and end times that are greater than one hour must be mutually agreed upon by the Employer and the Union.
logical_representation: IF shift_start_time_change_hours (llm) > 1 -> REQUIRE(MUTUAL_AGREEMENT)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for making significant changes to the work schedule, which is a core component of defining and managing worked time.

name: Consistent Application of Schedule Changes
rule_text: A  change  in  start/quit  times  shall  be  applied  consistently  on  the  jobsite...
summary: Any changes to shift start and end times must be applied consistently to everyone on the jobsite.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(APPLY_SCHEDULE_CHANGE_CONSISTENTLY_ON_JOBSITE)
reasoning: This is a constraint on how schedule changes are implemented, ensuring fairness in the application of work hours across a site.

name: Prohibition of Split Shifts
rule_text: ...and  in  no circumstances shall split shifts be created, unless mutually agreed between the parties.
summary: Split shifts are not allowed unless the Employer and the Union mutually agree to them.
logical_representation: IF is_split_shift (llm) == true -> REQUIRE(MUTUAL_AGREEMENT)
reasoning: This rule governs the structure of the workday, preventing non-continuous work periods which fundamentally alters how daily worked time is defined.

name: General Overtime Trigger
rule_text: Forty (40) hours shall constitute a work week, Monday through Friday. All other time worked shall be considered overtime and shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rate of pay.
summary: The standard work week is 40 hours, Monday through Friday. Any time worked beyond this is considered overtime and must be paid at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF weekly_hours > 40 OR day_of_week IN ('SAT', 'SUN') -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary conditions (exceeding 40 weekly hours or working outside Mon-Fri) under which hours are categorized as overtime, which is a core concept of labor time classification.

name: Daily Overtime Tier 1 (1.5x)
rule_text: The first two (2) hours of overtime per day, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at one and one half (1½) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday to Friday), the first two hours of overtime worked in a day are paid at 1.5 times the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN ('MON','TUE','WED','THU','FRI') AND daily_overtime_hours > 0 AND daily_overtime_hours <= 2 -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific pay rate for a specific tier of overtime hours. It is a fundamental rule for calculating pay based on the classification of worked time.

name: Daily Overtime Tier 2 (2.0x)
rule_text: All other overtime hours, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday to Friday), any overtime hours worked beyond the first two are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN ('MON','TUE','WED','THU','FRI') AND daily_overtime_hours > 2 -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for the second tier of daily overtime, which is a key part of calculating pay based on worked time classification.

name: Weekend and Holiday Overtime (2.0x)
rule_text: All hours worked on Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on Saturdays, Sundays, and Statutory Holidays are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN ('SAT', 'SUN') OR is_stat_holiday == true -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule specifies a special, elevated pay rate for work performed on specific days (weekends and holidays), directly impacting how those hours are categorized and paid.

name: Commercial/Institutional Overtime (1.5x)
rule_text: All hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours per day or forty (40) hours per week will be considered to be overtime hours and will be paid at the rate of one and one-half times the applicable rate of pay...
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, any hours worked beyond 8 in a day or 40 in a week are classified as overtime and paid at 1.5 times the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ('COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL') AND (daily_hours > 8 OR weekly_hours > 40) -> PREMIUM(1.5)
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative overtime calculation specific to certain project types. It's a key rule for categorizing worked time under specific conditions.

name: Commercial/Institutional Sunday & Holiday Overtime (2.0x)
rule_text: ...except for work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays which will be paid at double time.
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, all work performed on Sundays and Statutory Holidays is paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ('COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL') AND (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule is an exception to the Commercial/Institutional overtime rule, specifying a higher premium for certain days. This is a critical rule for correctly classifying and paying for worked time on these projects.

name: Overtime Calculation Point
rule_text: For  the  purposes  of  calculating  overtime  hours,  overtime  shall  normally  be  paid  upon  the completion  of  the  regular  days  shift.
summary: Overtime calculation and payment begin after an employee's regular daily shift is completed.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(CALCULATE_OVERTIME AFTER(REGULAR_SHIFT))
reasoning: This rule defines the procedural timing for when overtime begins to accrue, which is a key part of the logic for categorizing worked time.

name: Pre-Shift Work as Overtime
rule_text: When  an  Employee  is  required  to  work  prior  to  the commencement of their regular shift, such time shall be considered as overtime.
summary: Any time an employee is required to work before their regular shift starts is automatically considered overtime.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status (Unsupported) == 'PRE_SHIFT' -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies a special condition where work is immediately classified as overtime, overriding the normal daily hour thresholds. It's a direct rule about categorizing worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week Normal Day Definition
rule_text: The maximum of ten (10) hours shall constitute a normal day's work beginning at 7:00 AM and ending by 6:00 PM (except when one-half (½) hour lunch is taken in which case the normal day will end at 5:30 PM).
summary: For a compressed work week, a normal workday is a maximum of 10 hours, typically scheduled between 7:00 AM and 6:00 PM. If a half-hour lunch is taken, the day ends at 5:30 PM.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' -> SET(normal_daily_hours=10)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard number of straight-time hours in a day for a specific schedule, which is a core component of how worked time is categorized.

name: Compressed Work Week Normal Week Definition
rule_text: The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 7:00 AM and ending Thursday at 6:00 PM.
summary: The normal compressed work week is a maximum of 40 hours, scheduled from Monday morning to Thursday evening.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' -> SET(normal_weekly_hours=40, normal_work_days=['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'])
reasoning: This rule defines the standard days and total straight-time hours for a compressed work week, which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

name: No Guarantee of Hours
rule_text: The above schedule is intended to represent a normal workday or work week and is not to be construed as a guarantee of hours of work per day or per week or with respect to days in a week.
summary: The defined work schedules are not a guarantee that an employee will be provided that specific number of work hours or days.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(schedule_type != GUARANTEE_OF_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition on the interpretation of work schedules and hours, which directly impacts how time and pay are administered.

name: Minor Start/Quit Time Variation
rule_text: The Employer may vary the start/quit times by changing the scheduled starting time up to thirty minutes at their option.
summary: The employer has the right to adjust the scheduled start time by up to 30 minutes without requiring agreement.
logical_representation: IF start_time_variance_minutes (llm) <= 30 -> ALLOW(employer_discretion)
reasoning: This rule governs the scheduling of work hours, a key aspect of defining the workday and how time is recorded.

name: Major Start/Quit Time Variation
rule_text: Variances beyond thirty minutes shall be agreed mutually by the Employer and the Business Representative of the Union.
summary: Any changes to the start time greater than 30 minutes must be mutually agreed upon by the employer and the union.
logical_representation: IF start_time_variance_minutes (llm) > 30 -> REQUIRE(mutual_agreement)
reasoning: This rule places a condition on the scheduling of work hours, which is integral to the categorization of worked time.

name: Split Shift Prohibition
rule_text: A change in start/quit times shall be applied consistently on the jobsite and in no circumstances shall split shifts be created, unless mutually agreed between the parties.
summary: Changes to start and end times must be applied consistently across the jobsite, and creating split shifts is forbidden unless mutually agreed upon.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(NO_SPLIT_SHIFTS) UNLESS mutual_agreement == true
reasoning: This rule constrains how work shifts can be structured, a fundamental aspect of defining and categorizing worked time.

name: 4x10 Monday-Thursday Schedule
rule_text: The Employer may schedule the regular work week in four (4) consecutive ten (10) hour days, at straight time rates, provided only that the four (4) ten (10) hour days are scheduled during the Monday through Thursday period unless varied by mutual consent between the Employer and the Union.
summary: An employer can schedule a 4-day, 10-hour/day work week at straight time, provided these days are Monday through Thursday, unless otherwise mutually agreed.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' -> PAY(ST) FOR day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_hours <= 10
reasoning: This rule defines a specific work schedule (4x10) and its associated straight time pay conditions, which is a core rule for categorizing worked time.

name: 4x10 Friday Overtime
rule_text: On a four (4) ten (10) schedule, when Friday is worked, the first ten hours shall be paid at one and oneha1f (1½x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: When working a 4x10 (Monday-Thursday) schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Friday are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_hours <= 10 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the overtime rate for working on a scheduled day off within a particular work schedule, directly impacting how worked time is categorized and paid.

name: 10 on 4 off Schedule Definition
rule_text: A ten (10) on and four (4) off schedule may also be established as a compressed work week schedule and when utilized, the straight time days will be Tuesday through Friday in one week followed by Monday through Thursday in the subsequent week.
summary: A 10-on, 4-off compressed work week schedule can be used. The straight time days are Tuesday-Friday in the first week and Monday-Thursday in the second week.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('10_on_4_off')
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific, non-standard work schedule, which is fundamental to categorizing the time worked within that schedule.

name: 10 on 4 off Overtime on Scheduled Days Off
rule_text: Should an employee work on the scheduled days off, the Friday and Monday will be paid at time and one half (1½x), and the Saturday and Sunday will be paid at double time (2x).
summary: On a 10-on, 4-off schedule, if an employee works on their scheduled days off, the Friday and Monday are paid at time and a half, while the Saturday and Sunday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND is_scheduled_day_off (llm) == true AND day_of_week IN ['FRI', 'MON'] -> PREMIUM(1.5) ELSE IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND is_scheduled_day_off (llm) == true AND day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific overtime pay rates for working on scheduled days off under a particular schedule, which is a direct rule for categorizing worked time.

name: 10 on 4 off Optional Mid-Cycle Overtime
rule_text: When a ten (10) on and four (4) off schedule is utilized, overtime on the Saturday and Sunday that fall in the middle of the schedule will be optional.
summary: For employees on a 10-on, 4-off schedule, working overtime on the Saturday and Sunday that occur in the middle of the 10-day work block is optional.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] AND is_mid_cycle (llm) == true -> SET(overtime_work=optional)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition (optional vs. mandatory) for working overtime hours on specific days of a schedule, which affects labor time management.

name: Notice to Decline Optional Overtime
rule_text: Employees will be required to give seventy-two (72) hours' notice of their intention not to work such overtime. Failure to provide the required notice and report for work shall be considered absenteeism.
summary: To decline optional mid-cycle weekend overtime on a 10-on, 4-off schedule, an employee must provide 72 hours' notice. Failing to give notice and not showing up is considered absenteeism.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND wants_to_decline_optional_overtime (llm) == true -> REQUIRE(notice_period_hours >= 72)
reasoning: This rule sets a procedural requirement for managing overtime hours, which is part of administering worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week Daily Overtime
rule_text: Where these options are worked, all hours in excess of ten (10) hours per day Monday through Thursday, shall be paid for at two (2x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On a compressed work week schedule, any hours worked beyond 10 per day from Monday to Thursday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10', '10_on_4_off'] AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a clear threshold and pay rate for daily overtime under specific schedules, a primary function of categorizing worked time.

name: Commercial/Institutional Overtime Rate
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, all overtime hours on Commercial/Institutional projects shall be paid for at the rate of time and one-half
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects, all overtime hours are paid at time and a half, overriding other overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] -> PAY(OT) FOR all_overtime_hours
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to standard overtime calculations based on the type of project, directly affecting how worked time is categorized and paid.

name: Local 488 Sunday and Holiday Overtime
rule_text: except for work in Local 488's jurisdiction where work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at double time.
summary: As an exception for Commercial/Institutional projects, work performed on Sundays or Statutory Holidays within Local 488's jurisdiction is paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL'] AND union_local (Unsupported) == '488' AND (day_of_week == 'SUN' OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PREMIUM(2.0)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific overtime rate for certain days and a specific jurisdiction, overriding other rules. It is a key factor in categorizing worked time.

name: Notice for Change in Work Hours
rule_text: When job circumstances merit a change in the hours of work, the Employer shall notify the Union office at least seven (7) calendar days, where practical, before such change becomes effective.
summary: If job conditions require a change in the hours of work, the employer must notify the union office at least seven calendar days in advance, whenever practical.
logical_representation: IF change_in_work_hours (llm) == true -> REQUIRE(employer_notifies_union_7_days_prior)
reasoning: This rule dictates the notification process for altering work schedules, which is an administrative aspect of managing labor time.

name: Industrial Project Schedule Flexibility
rule_text: on job sites or where special conditions apply, scheduling of extended work weeks and/or days off may be beneficial to completion of the work. The Union and the Employer will mutually agree to a work schedule to meet job conditions.
summary: On industrial job sites with special conditions, the union and employer can mutually agree to customized work schedules, including extended weeks or different days off, to meet project needs.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'INDUSTRIAL' AND special_conditions_apply (llm) == true -> ALLOW(mutual_agreement_on_schedule)
reasoning: This rule allows for the creation of unique work schedules by mutual agreement under specific project conditions, fundamentally affecting how worked time is defined and tracked.

name: Personal Time Off Request
rule_text: An employee who has not been absent, including late arrivals or early quits, or granted leave in the previous calendar 30 days, and who gives the Employer at least three working days' notice of a request for leave of up to one day, will be granted the requested leave.
summary: An employee can be granted up to one day of personal leave if they have a clean attendance record for the past 30 days and provide at least three working days' notice.
logical_representation: IF prior_30_day_attendance_perfect (llm) == true AND notice_days (llm) >= 3 AND leave_duration_days (llm) <= 1 -> GRANT(personal_leave)
reasoning: This rule defines the conditions for taking time off, which affects the calculation of total worked hours and eligibility for weekly overtime.

name: Overtime Qualification with Pre-Authorized Absence
rule_text: A worker who is preauthorized to take personal time off pursuant to the above procedure, will qualify for overtime premiums for any work performed either preceding or following the normal scheduled hours of work on the day they take their personal absence regardless of whether or not they have worked the full eight or ten hours as scheduled for that shift.
summary: If a worker has pre-authorized personal time off, they are still eligible for daily overtime pay for hours worked beyond their normal shift on that day, even if they didn't work a full day.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == true -> ELIGIBLE_FOR_OT_PREMIUMS(daily_overtime)
reasoning: This rule clarifies how an authorized absence interacts with daily overtime calculation, a key aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Pre-Authorized Absence and Weekly Overtime
rule_text: It is also understood that, provided such absences conform to these conditions, the absence will not disqualify the worker from working overtime scheduled for that week.
summary: A pre-authorized personal day off does not disqualify a worker from being able to work other scheduled overtime during that same week.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == true -> RETAIN(eligibility_for_weekly_overtime_work)
reasoning: This rule defines how absences affect eligibility for weekly overtime, directly impacting the administration of worked time.

name: Standard Daily Overtime Threshold
rule_text: Overtime premiums as specified in this Collective Agreement will be paid for all hours worked in excess of eight hours in a day.
summary: Overtime pay applies to all hours worked beyond eight in a single day.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 8 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This is a fundamental rule that defines the threshold for daily overtime, which is core to categorizing worked hours.

name: Compressed Work Week Overtime Thresholds
rule_text: In the case of a compressed work week, overtime premiums will be paid for hours worked in excess of ten in a day or forty in a week.
summary: For a compressed work week, overtime is paid for hours exceeding ten in a day or forty in a week.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type IN ['4x10', '10_on_4_off'] AND (daily_hours > 10 OR weekly_hours > 40) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific daily and weekly overtime thresholds for a compressed work week schedule, a primary function of categorizing worked time.

name: Unexcused Absence and Overtime Disqualification
rule_text: A worker that is absent from work without pre-authorization as per the above procedure, including late arrivals or early quits will be subject to discipline in accordance with their employer's policies and may also be disqualified from working scheduled overtime in the week the absence occurs.
summary: An unexcused absence, including being late or leaving early, can result in discipline and may disqualify the worker from any scheduled overtime for that week.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == false -> FORFEIT(weekly_scheduled_overtime_work)
reasoning: This rule connects attendance (an aspect of labor time) with eligibility for overtime hours, thus it pertains to the administration of worked time.

name: Unexcused Absence Overtime Pay Trigger
rule_text: Workers who are absent from work without pre-authorization, must work the minimum normal hours as stipulated above prior to overtime premiums being paid.
summary: If a worker has an unexcused absence, they must complete their full normal daily hours (e.g., 8 or 10) before any subsequent hours qualify for overtime pay.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == false -> REQUIRE(daily_hours > normal_daily_hours) BEFORE PAY(OT)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for earning overtime based on attendance, directly impacting how hours are categorized from straight time to overtime.

name: Weekly Overtime with Unexcused Absence
rule_text: If scheduled straight time hours are missed due to unexcused absences the worker must work their straight time hours scheduled before overtime hours are earned.
summary: If a worker has an unexcused absence during the week, they must first make up the missed straight-time hours before any hours in that week are paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF unexcused_absence_hours_in_week (llm) > 0 -> REQUIRE(weekly_hours > 40) BEFORE PAY(OT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a 'make-up' requirement for weekly overtime calculation following an unexcused absence, which is a key rule in categorizing total weekly hours.

name: Excusable Absence Definition
rule_text: The employee will notify the employer prior to shift start time, to be accepted as an excusable absence when circumstances arise beyond the workers' control.
summary: An absence is considered excusable if it's due to circumstances beyond the worker's control and the employee notifies the employer before their shift starts.
logical_representation: IF notification_before_shift_start (llm) == true AND reason_beyond_control (llm) == true -> SET(absence=excusable)
reasoning: This rule defines what constitutes an excusable absence, which is critical for determining overtime eligibility as per other rules. It's an integral part of managing worked time.

name: Call Out Pay, No Work Commenced
rule_text: Employees who have completed the day's scheduled hours of work and left the jobsite to return home or to camp and who respond to a request to work additional time, shall be compensated as follows. (a) Employees who do not commence work shall be paid for two (2) hours at the applicable overtime rate, and any travel and transportation applicable.
summary: An employee who has finished their shift, left the site, and is then called back but does not start work, must be paid for a minimum of two hours at the overtime rate, plus any applicable travel costs.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out (llm) == true AND work_commenced (Unsupported) == false -> PAY(MIN(2_HOURS_OT)) AND PAY(TRAVEL_COST)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee for a specific work scenario (a call-out where no work is performed), which falls under the category of how worked/guaranteed time is compensated.

name: Call Out Pay, Work Commenced Minimum
rule_text: Employees who are called in and commence work shall be paid for a minimum of three (3) hours at the applicable overtime rate and any travel and transportation applicable.
summary: An employee who is called back to the site after their shift and begins working is guaranteed a minimum payment of three hours at the overtime rate, in addition to any applicable travel costs.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out (llm) == true AND work_commenced (Unsupported) == true -> PAY(MIN(3_HOURS_OT)) AND PAY(TRAVEL_COST)
reasoning: This rule sets a minimum payment guarantee for time worked under specific conditions (a call-out), which is a core function of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Call Out Pay, Exceeding Minimum
rule_text: Where an Employee works more than the three (3) hours set out in 18.01 (b) above, the Employee shall receive remuneration for the hours actually worked at the applicable overtime rates and any travel or transportation applicable.
summary: If an employee on a call-out works for more than the three-hour minimum, they are to be paid for all the hours they actually worked at the applicable overtime rate, plus any travel costs.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out (llm) == true AND work_commenced (Unsupported) == true AND call_out_hours_worked (llm) > 3 -> PAY(call_out_hours_worked (llm) * OT_RATE) AND PAY(TRAVEL_COST)
reasoning: This rule defines how hours worked beyond a minimum guarantee are calculated and paid, which is a direct aspect of categorizing and compensating labor time.

name: Rest Period After Call Out
rule_text: In the event that an Employee, responding to a call out does not get an eight (8) hour break, prior to the commencement of their regular workday, the Employee(s) shall be allowed an eight (8) hour rest break and be paid for a normally scheduled workday. To qualify for the normally scheduled days pay the Employee shall be available for work at the end of the eight (8) hour break.
summary: If a call-out prevents an employee from getting an eight-hour break before their next regular shift, they are entitled to an eight-hour rest break. They will be paid for their normal workday provided they are available to work immediately after this rest period ends.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out (llm) == true AND break_between_shifts_hours (llm) < 8 AND is_available_for_work (llm) == true -> PROVIDE(8_HOUR_REST_BREAK) AND PAY(NORMAL_SCHEDULED_WORKDAY)
reasoning: This rule provides an entitlement for a paid rest period and payment for a regular workday under specific circumstances related to insufficient rest. This falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it dictates how time is compensated due to work scheduling conflicts.

name: Shift Work Minimum Duration and Frequency
rule_text: when shift work is performed at least two (2) full shifts must be worked in any twenty-four (24) hour period and each of these shifts must continue for at least five (5) consecutive regular working days, or four (4) consecutive regular working days where the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is being utilized.
summary: To qualify as shift work, there must be at least two full shifts within a 24-hour period. These shifts must last for a minimum of 5 consecutive days on a standard schedule, or 4 consecutive days on a 4x10 compressed work week schedule.
logical_representation: IF shift_work_is_performed (llm) == true -> CONSTRAINT(number_of_shifts_in_24h (llm) >= 2) AND ((schedule_type == '5x8' AND shift_consecutive_days >= 5) OR (schedule_type == '4x10' AND shift_consecutive_days >= 4))
reasoning: This rule defines the minimum conditions and duration required for a work pattern to be considered 'shift work', which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Penalty for Shifts Shorter Than Minimum Duration
rule_text: Should each of the shifts outlined above not continue for a period of four (4) or five (5) consecutive working days, all hours worked shall be deemed overtime and paid at the applicable rates contained in this Agreement.
summary: If a shift schedule does not run for the minimum required duration (4 or 5 consecutive days depending on the schedule), all hours worked on that shift must be paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF (schedule_type == '5x8' AND shift_consecutive_days < 5) OR (schedule_type == '4x10' AND shift_consecutive_days < 4) -> TRANSITION(ALL_HOURS_TO_OT)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific payment outcome (all hours as overtime) based on the duration of a shift, directly impacting how worked time is calculated and paid.

name: Shift Premium for Partial Weeks
rule_text: Where a shift is commenced and has run for at least the four (4) or five (5) consecutive days referred to above, should the shift terminate in the middle of the week, or an Employee hires on in a week in which a shift ends, affected Employee(s) shall only be entitled to shift premium on regular hours of work.
summary: If a qualifying shift ends mid-week or an employee is hired mid-week, the shift premium is only paid on their regular (straight-time) hours for that week.
logical_representation: IF shift_termination_midweek (llm) == true OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'NEW_HIRE' -> PREMIUM(SHIFT_PREMIUM_ON_ST_HOURS_ONLY)
reasoning: This rule specifies the conditions under which a premium is applied to hours worked, which is a core component of labor time calculation and compensation.

name: Waiver of Overtime Penalty for Short Shifts by Mutual Agreement
rule_text: By mutual agreement, shifts may be established for periods of less than four (4) or five (5) consecutive regular working days and in such an event, the deemed overtime that would otherwise be payable shall not apply.
summary: The penalty of paying all hours as overtime for short shifts can be waived if both parties mutually agree to establish a shift for a shorter duration.
logical_representation: IF is_mutual_agreement (llm) == true AND shift_consecutive_days < 4 -> FORFEIT(DEEMED_OT_PENALTY)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to a standard overtime payment rule, directly affecting how worked time is categorized and paid under specific circumstances.

name: First Shift Overtime Thresholds
rule_text: The first shift shall work a normal shift as set out in Clause 16.01 and/or 17.01 of this Agreement, with the applicable overtime rate after eight (8) hours of work or in excess of ten (10) hours per day during a compressed work week.
summary: For the first (day) shift, overtime rates apply after 8 hours on a standard workday or after 10 hours on a compressed work week day.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'DAY' AND ((schedule_type == '5x8' AND daily_hours > 8) OR (schedule_type == '4x10' AND daily_hours > 10)) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the daily thresholds for when straight time ends and overtime begins for a specific shift type, which is a primary function of categorizing worked time.

name: Alternate Shift Start Time Definition
rule_text: Shift work other than the normal shift as outlined in Clause 19.03 may be utilized provided such shift(s) commence between 3.00 PM and 6.00 AM.
summary: Any shift that is not the normal (first) shift is considered an alternate shift if it starts between 3:00 PM and 6:00 AM.
logical_representation: IF shift_start_time (llm) >= '15:00' AND shift_start_time (llm) <= '06:00' -> SET(shift_type = 'ALTERNATE')
reasoning: This rule defines what constitutes an 'alternate shift' based on its start time, which is a condition for applying specific pay rules and premiums related to worked time.

name: Alternate Shift Premium (Effective May 2025)
rule_text: The hourly rate for Employees on any alternate shift(s) as outlined above shall be $4.00 per hour effective May 4 th , 2025 ... greater than the applicable day time rate of pay.
summary: Effective May 4, 2025, employees working on an alternate shift (starting between 3 PM and 6 AM) receive a premium of $4.00 per hour.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'ALTERNATE' AND validity_start_date >= '2025-05-04' AND validity_end_date < '2026-05-03' -> PREMIUM($4.00)
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary premium for hours worked on a specific shift type, directly impacting the calculation of labor costs.

name: Alternate Shift Premium (Effective May 2026)
rule_text: The hourly rate for Employees on any alternate shift(s) as outlined above shall be ... ($4.50 effective May 3, 2026) greater than the applicable day time rate of pay.
summary: Effective May 3, 2026, the premium for employees working on an alternate shift (starting between 3 PM and 6 AM) increases to $4.50 per hour.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'ALTERNATE' AND validity_start_date >= '2026-05-03' -> PREMIUM($4.50)
reasoning: This rule specifies a scheduled increase in a monetary premium for hours worked on a specific shift type, directly impacting the calculation of labor costs.

name: Maximum Hourly Rate on Alternate Shifts
rule_text: In no event shall this hourly rate be greater than the applicable overtime rate plus shift differential.
summary: The total hourly pay for an alternate shift cannot exceed the amount that would be paid for overtime plus the shift differential.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'ALTERNATE' -> CONSTRAINT(total_hourly_rate <= overtime_rate + shift_differential)
reasoning: This rule sets a ceiling on pay rates under specific conditions, which is a constraint on the calculation of labor worked time and pay.

name: Single Shift per 24-Hour Period
rule_text: No Employee shall work more than one (1) straight time shift in each consecutive twenty-four (24) hour period.
summary: An employee is not permitted to work more than one straight-time shift within any 24-hour period.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(number_of_st_shifts_in_24h (llm) <= 1)
reasoning: This rule establishes a constraint on work scheduling that directly relates to how hours are categorized and paid, preventing multiple straight-time periods in a short timeframe.

name: Overtime Until 8-Hour Rest Break
rule_text: An Employee shall continue to receive the overtime rate, plus shift differential, after each shift until a break of eight (8) consecutive hours occurs, exclusive of travel allowance.
summary: If an employee does not receive at least an 8-hour consecutive break between shifts, all hours worked until that break occurs will be paid at the overtime rate plus any applicable shift differential.
logical_representation: IF rest_period_hours (llm) < 8 -> TRANSITION(OT_PLUS_SHIFT_DIFFERENTIAL)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (insufficient rest) that triggers overtime pay, directly impacting the classification and payment of worked hours.

name: Pay for Day Lost Due to Shift Change
rule_text: When an Employee loses a regular day through the implementation or termination of shift work, then the Employee shall be paid a regular days pay for the day lost.
summary: If an employee loses a scheduled workday because of the start or end of a shift work schedule, they must be paid for that lost day.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_causes_lost_day (llm) == true -> PAY(ONE_REGULAR_DAY)
reasoning: This rule provides a payment entitlement for time not actually worked but lost due to scheduling changes, which is a form of guaranteed pay related to labor time.

name: Shift Premium for Irregular Single Shifts
rule_text: Where the owner/client may require work to be done on a single shift basis at start/quit times that may be at variance with the start/quit for a regular shift, single shift operations shall be permitted subject to the payment of shift differential. The shift differential shall be paid on all hours worked.
summary: If a client requires a single shift with non-standard start and end times, a shift differential must be paid for all hours worked on that shift.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift (Unsupported) == true -> PREMIUM(SHIFT_DIFFERENTIAL_ON_ALL_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule mandates a premium payment based on the specific scheduling characteristics of the work, directly affecting the pay rate for worked time.

name: Overtime for Irregular Single Shifts
rule_text: Overtime shall be payable on all hours in excess of eight (8) hours per day, or in excess of ten (10) hours per day during a compressed work week, and forty (40) hours per week and on Saturdays, Sundays, or Statutory Holidays.
summary: For irregular single shifts, overtime is paid for hours over 8 daily (or 10 on a compressed schedule), over 40 weekly, and for all hours worked on Saturdays, Sundays, or Statutory Holidays.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift (Unsupported) == true AND ((schedule_type == '5x8' AND daily_hours > 8) OR (schedule_type == '4x10' AND daily_hours > 10) OR weekly_hours > 40 OR day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the multiple conditions (daily, weekly, day-of-week, holiday) that trigger overtime pay for a specific type of work, which is a core rule for categorizing worked time.

name: First Overtime Meal after 10 Hours
rule_text: Where Employees are required to work in excess of ten (10) hours in a single shift, they shall be provided immediately after ten (10) hours, with a suitable meal (hot where possible)
summary: An employee working more than 10 hours in a single shift must be given a suitable meal (preferably hot) immediately after the 10th hour of work.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_1)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to a meal based on hours worked, which is the core definition of a meal allowance rule.

name: Subsequent Overtime Meals Every 4 Hours
rule_text: ...and every four (4) hours thereafter until the shift is ended.
summary: After the first overtime meal at 10 hours, another meal is provided for every additional 4 hours worked until the end of the shift.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND (daily_hours - 10) % 4 == 0 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_SUBSEQUENT)
reasoning: This rule dictates the frequency of subsequent meal entitlements after an initial threshold, a classic meal allowance condition.

name: Payment for Overtime Meal Consumption Time
rule_text: The cost of the meal(s) and the time consuming same shall be paid for at the straight time rates contained in this Agreement, to a maximum of one half (½) hour in duration.
summary: The employer pays for the overtime meal itself and for the time taken to eat it, up to a maximum of 30 minutes, at the employee's straight-time rate.
logical_representation: ON (PROVIDE(MEAL)) -> PAY(MEAL_COST) AND PAY(0.5_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the compensation associated with the meal entitlement (cost of meal and paid time to eat), which is directly related to the meal allowance topic.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement on Subsistence Jobs
rule_text: Where the Employer is paying subsistence, this clause shall also apply.
summary: The overtime meal rules apply even when the employee is already receiving a subsistence allowance from the employer.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_subsistence (llm) == true -> APPLY_RULE(20.01)
reasoning: This rule clarifies the applicability of meal allowance rules under another specific condition (receiving subsistence), thus it's categorized under meal allowances.

name: Meal Allowance In-Lieu When Meal is Impractical
rule_text: On projects when it is impractical for the contractor to provide a meal the employee shall be paid a 15-minute paid break at the applicable rate of pay and the employer shall pay a meal allowance of $45.00 in lieu of the meal and the time to consume the meal.
summary: If the employer cannot provide a meal on a project, the employee receives a $45.00 meal allowance plus a 15-minute paid break at their current pay rate instead.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND is_meal_provided (llm) == false -> ALLOWANCE(45.00) AND PAY(0.25_HOURS_APPLICABLE_RATE)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary allowance and a paid break as a substitute for a physical meal, a core function of meal allowance policies.

name: Meal Allowance Exception with Camp Supper
rule_text: Where a shift in excess of 10 hours but not longer than 12 hours is worked, when camp accommodations are provided and a full course hot supper is provided at the end of the shift, no meal allowance shall be payable.
summary: For shifts between 10 and 12 hours, if the employee is in a camp and receives a hot supper after their shift, no overtime meal or allowance is provided.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND daily_hours <= 12 AND has_camp_accommodation (llm) == true AND is_camp_supper_provided (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This is an explicit exception to the meal allowance entitlement under specific accommodation and meal provision conditions.

name: Break Time Adjustment for Camp Shifts
rule_text: When such shifts are worked, break times may be adjusted for efficiency and reasonableness.
summary: On shifts where the camp supper meal exception applies (10-12 hours), break times can be adjusted by the employer for efficiency after notifying the Union.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND daily_hours <= 12 AND has_camp_accommodation (llm) == true AND is_camp_supper_provided (llm) == true -> ALLOW(ADJUST_BREAK_TIMES)
reasoning: This rule concerns the scheduling and timing of work breaks, which falls under the management of worked time. The meal condition is the trigger.

name: Union Notification for Break Adjustments
rule_text: In such cases the Union will be notified prior to the breaks being adjusted.
summary: The employer must inform the Union before changing break times on shifts where the camp supper meal exception is in effect.
logical_representation: ON (ADJUST_BREAK_TIMES) -> REQUIRE(NOTIFY_UNION)
reasoning: This is a procedural requirement related to the adjustment of break times, which is part of managing worked time.

name: Meal Exception for 1-Hour Unplanned Overtime
rule_text: Recognizing emergency or unplanned situations may arise intermittently, if the Contractor has not scheduled in excess of the ten (10) hour shift, the Contractor shall be granted a one (1) hour extension where the Contractor need not supply a hot meal or make payment in lieu of
summary: If overtime is unplanned and a shift extends from 10 hours to no more than 11 hours, the employer is not required to provide a meal or meal allowance.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND daily_hours <= 11 AND is_overtime_scheduled (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule creates a specific conditional exception to the meal allowance rule based on the nature of the overtime (unplanned).

name: Paid Break for 1-Hour Unplanned Overtime
rule_text: however; a fifteen (15) minute rest break paid at the applicable rate will be taken at the tenth (10 th ) hour.
summary: In cases of a 1-hour unplanned overtime extension (up to 11 hours total), employees receive a 15-minute paid rest break at the 10-hour mark.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 AND daily_hours <= 11 AND is_overtime_scheduled (llm) == false -> PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(0.25_HOURS)) AT(10_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule mandates a paid break, which is a component of how an employee's time is managed and compensated, classifying it under worked time.

name: Maximum Shift without Meal Entitlement is 11 Hours
rule_text: Under no circumstance shall any Employee work more than eleven (11) hours without adherence to Clause 20.01.
summary: An employee cannot work more than 11 hours in a single shift without receiving the standard overtime meal or allowance as per clause 20.01.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 11 -> ENFORCE(RULE(20.01))
reasoning: This rule sets a non-negotiable threshold for triggering the meal allowance rules, making it a critical constraint on that topic.

name: Supervisor Meal Exception for Short Early/Late Work
rule_text: Where a supervisor is required to; (i) start up to one (1) hour earlier, or (ii) finish up to one (1) hour later, or (iii) start up to one half (½) hour earlier and finish up to one half (½) hour later than the supervisor's crew, for the purposes of organizing work or facilitating a transition to another shift, the provisions of 20.01 will not apply unless those provisions are applicable to the rest of the crew.
summary: A supervisor working slightly earlier or later than their crew for prep or handover is not entitled to an overtime meal under those specific conditions, unless the rest of the crew is also entitled.
logical_representation: IF is_foreman == true AND (supervisor_extra_hours (llm) <= 1.0) AND crew_meal_entitlement_status (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule explicitly negates the meal allowance entitlement for a specific role (supervisor) under defined circumstances, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Show Up Time Minimum Pay
rule_text: When an Employee reports to work at the regular starting time and such Employee is not put to work,  the  Employee  so  affected  shall  be  entitled  to  a  minimum  of  two  (2)  hours  pay  at  the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If an employee reports for their regular shift but is not put to work, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours of pay at their applicable rate.
logical_representation: IF reports_for_work (llm) == true AND is_put_to_work (llm) == false -> PAY(MIN(2_HOURS))
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee for an employee who reports to work but is not provided with any, which is a form of guaranteed worked time.

name: Show Up Time On-Site Requirement
rule_text: In  order  to  qualify  for  show  up  time,  Employees  must  remain  on  the  jobsite  unless  otherwise directed by the Employer.
summary: To receive show-up pay, employees must stay on the jobsite unless the employer instructs them to leave.
logical_representation: IF employee_remains_on_site (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(SHOW_UP_PAY)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for the eligibility of show-up pay, directly affecting whether an employee is compensated for their time, thus falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Extended Wait Time Pay
rule_text: Where the Employee(s) are directed to remain at the jobsite for more than two (2) hours, including wait times for company supplied transportation to leave site, they shall be paid for such time at the applicable rate.
summary: If an employee is required to wait on the jobsite for more than two hours (including waiting for company transport), they must be paid for the entire duration of the wait.
logical_representation: IF wait_time_on_site_hours (llm) > 2 -> PAY(wait_time_on_site_hours (llm))
reasoning: This rule mandates payment for time spent waiting on-site beyond a specific threshold, making it a rule about compensable labor time.

name: Show Up Time and Allowances
rule_text: Employee(s)  affected  shall  be  paid  daily  travel,  transportation,  subsistence  or  receive  camp accommodation as is applicable.
summary: Employees who qualify for show-up pay are also entitled to receive their applicable daily travel, transportation, subsistence, or camp accommodation benefits.
logical_representation: IF is_show_up_time_qualified (llm) == true -> PROVIDE(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE) AND PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION_ALLOWANCE) AND PROVIDE(SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE) AND PROVIDE(CAMP_ACCOMMODATION)
reasoning: This rule directly concerns the provision of subsistence, travel, and accommodation allowances, which falls under the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Show Up Time Notification Exception
rule_text: An Employee is not entitled to show up time if the Employer notifies the Employee that no work is available at least two (2) hours prior to the commencement of the normal workday.
summary: An employee is not eligible for show-up pay if the employer informs them of the lack of work at least two hours before their normal start time.
logical_representation: IF notification_of_no_work_hours_prior (llm) >= 2 -> FORFEIT(SHOW_UP_PAY)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to the show-up pay entitlement based on timely notification, making it a conditional rule about guaranteed labor payments.

name: Show Up Time Camp Notification Exception
rule_text: Employees working on a jobsite where they are accommodated in a camp facility will not be entitled to show up time if they are notified that no work is available, at breakfast time, and notices are posted on the bulletin boards in the camp kitchen.
summary: Employees living in a work camp are not entitled to show-up pay if they are notified at breakfast and a notice is posted in the camp kitchen that there is no work available.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_employee (llm) == true AND is_notified_at_breakfast (llm) == true AND is_notice_posted (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(SHOW_UP_PAY)
reasoning: This rule specifies a particular set of conditions for camp-based employees that negates the show-up pay entitlement, thereby defining when guaranteed work time is not paid.

name: Show Up Time and Shift Premium
rule_text: When an Employee reporting for work qualifies for show up time such time shall include the regular shift premium when applicable.
summary: When an employee receives show-up pay, that pay must include any applicable regular shift premium.
logical_representation: IF is_show_up_time_qualified (llm) == true AND has_shift_premium (llm) == true -> PAY(SHOW_UP_HOURS_WITH_PREMIUM)
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation method for show-up pay, specifically the inclusion of premiums, which is a core component of how worked or guaranteed time is compensated.

name: Definition of Local Resident
rule_text: A local resident is an individual who resides within a seventy-five (75) kilometer radius of the  centre  of  a  job  site  which  is  beyond  daily  commuting  distance  from  Edmonton  or Calgary or other locations where a hiring hall is located and, has resided within such radius of the site for a period of not less than six months prior to being engaged on the project.
summary: A local resident is defined as someone who has lived for at least six months within a 75 km radius of a job site, provided the site is outside daily commuting distance from a major city or hiring hall location.
logical_representation: IF job_location_radius_km (Unsupported) <= 75 AND residency_duration_months (llm) >= 6 AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > daily_commuting_distance (llm) -> SET(is_local_resident (Unsupported), true)
reasoning: This rule defines the criteria for being a 'local resident', which is the primary condition for eligibility for various subsistence, travel, and accommodation allowances. Therefore, it is classified under LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE.

name: Forfeiture of Allowances for Local Residents within 45km
rule_text: Local Residents residing within a forty-five (45) km radius of the job site shall not be entitled to receive transportation or vehicle allowance, travel allowance, initial and return travel allowance, room and board, subsistence, camp accommodations, or rotational leave provisions.
summary: Local residents who live within a 45 km radius of the job site are not eligible for any transportation, travel, living, or accommodation allowances, nor are they entitled to rotational leave.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true AND job_location_radius_km (Unsupported) <= 45 -> FORFEIT('transportation_allowance', 'vehicle_allowance', 'travel_allowance', 'initial_and_return_travel_allowance', 'room_and_board', 'subsistence', 'camp_accommodations', 'rotational_leave')
reasoning: This rule explicitly removes entitlement to various monetary and in-kind allowances related to living out and travel based on the employee's proximity to the worksite. This falls directly under the category of LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE.

name: Forfeiture of Major Allowances for Industrial Local Residents 45-75km
rule_text: Local residents residing between a forty-five (45) km radius and a seventy-five (75) km radius of the job site shall not be entitled to receive initial and return travel allowance, room and board or subsistence, or camp accommodations, or rotational leave provisions
summary: For industrial projects, local residents living between 45 km and 75 km from the job site are not eligible for initial/return travel, room and board, subsistence, camp accommodations, or rotational leave.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'INDUSTRIAL' AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true AND job_location_radius_km (Unsupported) > 45 AND job_location_radius_km (Unsupported) <= 75 -> FORFEIT('initial_and_return_travel_allowance', 'room_and_board', 'subsistence', 'camp_accommodations', 'rotational_leave')
reasoning: Similar to the previous rule, this specifies the forfeiture of significant living-out and travel benefits for a specific subset of employees, making it a rule about subsistence and related allowances.

name: Travel Allowance for Industrial Local Residents 45-75km (No Employer Transport)
rule_text: Local residents residing between a forty-five (45) km radius and a seventy-five (75) km radius of the job site... shall be paid a travel allowance of thirty-three dollars ($33.00) per day worked ($36.00 per day worked effective May 4/09) to cover transportation expenses and travel allowance
summary: On industrial projects, local residents living 45-75 km from the site receive a daily travel allowance if the employer does not provide transportation. The rate is $33.00 per day worked, increasing to $36.00 effective May 4, 2009.
